articles.title: Reform UK revokes membership of council leader accused of racism
articles.trailText: Party removes Ian Cooper after he was alleged to have abused Sadiq Khan, David Lammy and other figures online
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage has revoked membership of Staffordshire county council leader Ian Cooper after revelations of racist online posts. Cooper allegedly insulted Sadiq Khan as a “narcissistic Pakistani,” attacked justice secretary David Lammy and barrister Shola Mos-Shogbamimu, and denounced migrants as intent on “colonising the UK.” He also questioned broadcasters’ Englishness and branded diversity schemes oppressive. Cooper, who stood as a Tamworth candidate in 2023 and 2024, lost his party post and council leadership; interim chair Martin Murray now leads the local group. Two other Reform UK politicians face suspensions.

articles.title: Labour launches child poverty strategy but hints costly welfare system has to change
articles.trailText: Work and pensions secretary Pat McFadden says more must be done to lift people out of hardship and help people into work
articles.summary: Work and Pensions Secretary Pat McFadden has unveiled Labour’s child poverty strategy, centring on abolishing the two-child universal credit limit at a £3bn cost to lift 450,000 children out of poverty by 2031. Accompanying measures include cheaper baby formula support, faster exits from temporary housing, breakfast clubs and free school lunches. McFadden stressed the plan as a long-term investment beyond cash distribution, and signalled further welfare reforms to drive work incentives and curb rising benefit costs. Two reviews (Timms on disability benefits; Milburn on youth inactivity) are underway, while he rejects claims this divides working and non-working families.

articles.title: Former Dulwich pupil says Farage told him: ‘That’s the way back to Africa’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Yinka Bankole says he felt compelled to speak out after Reform leader’s attempts to ‘dismiss’ hurt of alleged targets
articles.summary: Former Dulwich College pupil Yinka Bankole says he was targeted in 1980–81 as a nine-year-old by a 17-year-old Nigel Farage, who pointed to Africa and told him, “That’s the way back to Africa,” repeating the slur at the school gate. Bankole, now a 54-year-old engineer whose parents emigrated from Nigeria, went public after Farage’s press conference dismissing evidence of past racism or antisemitism as harmless banter amid a Guardian investigation. Farage denies any intent to hurt, but Bankole, one of 28 contemporaries alleging schoolboy bigotry, says the abuse was malicious and unforgettable.

articles.title: How Farage’s response to racism claims is straight out of Trump’s populist playbook
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader’s legal threats, denials and attacks on the media are tactics often deployed by US president
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage has responded to allegations of racist and antisemitic remarks in his school days by echoing Donald Trump’s populist playbook: issuing legal threats demanding retractions and damages, flat denials with caveats, smearing accusers like director Peter Ettedgui by questioning their motives, and blasting the media—especially the BBC—at press events. Critics across Westminster, including Lib Dem deputy leader Daisy Cooper, accuse him of importing “the very worst kind of American populist tricks,” though some note his denials remain more nuanced than Trump’s.

articles.title: Nigel Farage’s shifting answers on school-days racism claims – a timeline
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader’s responses to allegations of racist and antisemitic behaviour at Dulwich college have varied over time
articles.summary: Nigel Farage’s responses to decades-old allegations of racist and antisemitic behaviour at Dulwich College have evolved since 2013, from a tentative ‘depends how you define it’ to full legal denials in 2025. A 2013 Channel 4 interview saw him reject being labelled racist; in 2019 and 2021 he portrayed schoolboy insults as common, non-extremist banter; from October 2025 letters from his legal team categorically denied wrongdoing and threatened action; by November he publicly dismissed claims as unsubstantiated smears, insisting he never intended to racially abuse peers and demanding BBC apologies.

articles.title: UK-EU youth mobility scheme could let tens of thousands live and work abroad
articles.trailText: Ministers want to secure deal by end of 2026 as part of a broader reset of Britain’s relationship with Europe
articles.summary: By end of 2026, UK ministers aim to secure a youth mobility scheme with the EU granting tens of thousands of young people two-year visas to live and work abroad, capped and offset by reciprocal UK-to-EU moves. Negotiations—modeled on UK-Australia arrangements—cover participant age, distribution and net migration limits. Labour leaders Keir Starmer and David Lammy cite Brexit’s economic impact to argue for closer ties. The EU is pushing for a four-year cap. Talks began in September alongside a wider post-Brexit reset on food standards and carbon trading.

articles.title: Holocaust survivors call on Nigel Farage to apologise over alleged antisemitic comments
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Group’s open letter says Reform UK leader must take responsibility for behaviour as a schoolboy
articles.summary: Holocaust survivors led by Hedi Argent, Simon Winston and Anita Lasker-Wallfisch have written to Reform UK leader Nigel Farage demanding he acknowledge or deny playground remarks allegedly praising Hitler, mocking gas chambers and hurling antisemitic slurs at Jewish peers at Dulwich College. The letter, seen by the Guardian, warns of the 'danger of hateful words' and urges honesty and an apology. It follows testimony from 28 former classmates and teachers, including Peter Ettedgui, and dismissive rebuttals from deputy leader Richard Tice, who branded witnesses liars with a 'political axe to grind.'

articles.title: Explaining UK debt with biscuits: Labour MPs get the hang of viral content
articles.trailText: Gordon McKee, whose explainer has racked up 3m views, leads way as party tries to harness power of social media
articles.summary: Gordon McKee (MP for Glasgow South) has gone viral with a 101-second X video using stacks of custard creams and chocolate bourbons to visualise the UK’s debt-to-GDP ratio, amassing over 3.3 million views. The only Labour backbencher to hire a digital content creator, he’s inspired imitators—Richard Burgon’s 200-packet pasta clip (650k+ views), Jeevun Sandher’s Bond-rate explainer—while Keir Starmer’s “Operation Second Term” rolls out party-wide digital campaigning training. Junior ministers and some cabinet figures now embrace bite-sized TikTok, Instagram and YouTube Shorts to reach wider, non-traditional audiences.

articles.title: Farage turns on broadcasters over racism allegations as number of claims hits 28
articles.trailText: Reform leader suggests he would boycott BBC, saying he has had letter from Dulwich pupils defending him
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage attacked BBC and ITV in a London press conference, threatening a BBC boycott after 28 former Dulwich College classmates told the Guardian he made racist and antisemitic remarks as a teen. Claims include Peter Ettedgui’s account of Farage growling “Hitler was right” and making “gas them” noises, corroborated by eight peers. Farage denied malice, calling his behaviour “banter,” read a supportive letter from a Jewish ex-pupil and accused broadcasters of 1970s–80s hypocrisy. Labour leader Keir Starmer called him a “toxic, divisive disgrace.”

articles.title: Christopher Harborne, the ‘intensely private’ mega-donor bankrolling Reform UK
articles.trailText: He has made an immense fortune in crypto and – from his Thai retreat – is putting it at the service of Nigel Farage after a flirtation with the Tories
articles.summary: Reform UK’s top backer Christopher Harborne, a Cambridge-educated McKinsey alumnus turned crypto investor, has funnelled £9m into Nigel Farage’s party—his largest UK political donation—after previous £10m to the Brexit party in 2019 and £2.5m to the Tories in 2022. Based in Thailand under the alias Chakrit Sakunkrit, Harborne built a fortune via early stakes in bitcoin, Ethereum and a 12% share in Tether, the US-pegged stablecoin whose reserves generated $13bn profit in 2024. Intensely private, he lives at a wellness retreat, funds Thai charities and avoids media, yet wields political influence amid concerns over crypto’s use in money laundering.

articles.title: Tice steps up for Farage over past racism claims – and gets nothing in return | John Crace
articles.trailText: You could call it an act of friendship, except Nige sees Dicky less as a friend and more as a useful idiot
articles.summary: Deputy Reform UK leader Richard Tice publicly championed Nigel Farage on BBC’s Today programme, denouncing former pupils’ claims of antisemitic jokes as “made-up twaddle” and branding the cancellation of four mayoral elections a deliberate plot by the BBC and government to halt Reform’s rise. Despite risking libel, Tice’s over-the-top defence reveals his desperation for Farage’s favour. Later, at a separate press conference, Farage declined to endorse Tice, instead lashing out at the BBC’s historical racism and leaving Tice isolated. The episode underscores internal Reform infighting, as Farage alternates between prospects Zia Yusuf, Jonathan Gullis and Tice himself.

articles.title: No 10 to delay four England mayoral elections amid accusations of ‘cancelling democracy’
articles.trailText: Ministers will argue that four newly created mayoralties need more time to complete reorganisation
articles.summary: The UK government will delay inaugural mayoral elections in four new English combined authorities—Greater Essex, Norfolk and Suffolk, Hampshire and the Solent, and Sussex and Brighton—from 2026 to May 2028, citing the need to complete local government reorganisations and establish unitary councils. Opposition parties, including Labour, the Conservatives, Liberal Democrats and Reform UK, accuse Downing Street of 'cancelling democracy' and breaching trust. MPs demanded clarity on the £200m funding pledged to these regions. Reform UK leaders are exploring a judicial review, while ministers defend the postponement as necessary to build effective strategic authorities.

articles.title: Nigel Farage denies saying anything racist ‘with malice’ as he attacks BBC
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader launches tirade against broadcaster in latest effort to address claims of abuse from school contemporaries
articles.summary: Nigel Farage denies ever making racist remarks “with malice” while refusing to call accusers liars, amid allegations of antisemitic comments at Dulwich College. He lashed out at the BBC and presenter Emma Barnett, demanding apologies for 1970s–80s programmes like The Black and White Minstrel Show. Reading a letter from a Jewish former classmate, he argued claims are politically motivated, and recollections vary. He likewise sidestepped deputy Richard Tice’s dismissal of pupil testimony as “twaddle.” Labour’s Anna Turley and Conservatives challenged his inconsistent denials and suggested he owes apologies to alleged victims.

articles.title: Nigel Farage urged to sack Reform council leader accused of racism
articles.trailText: Party is investigating Ian Cooper as Labour MPs call for him to resign as leader of Staffordshire county council
articles.summary: Nigel Farage faces calls to sack Ian Cooper, Reform UK’s leader of Staffordshire county council and ex-Tamworth candidate, after social media posts surfaced calling Sadiq Khan a “narcissistic Pakistani,” urging Dr Shola Mos-Shogbamimu to “F-off back to Nigeria,” opposing foreign-born MPs and warning migrants are “intent on colonising the UK.” Nine Labour MPs and anti-fascist group Hope Not Hate demand his resignation as Reform launches an urgent probe into undisclosed accounts. Cooper hasn’t responded; critics say his white supremacist views breach public office duties. Two other Reform figures were recently suspended.

articles.title: Crypto investor gives £9m to Reform UK as donations exceed those to Tories
articles.trailText: Christopher Harborne’s record gift revealed in Electoral Commission figures prompts renewed calls for cap on political donations
articles.summary: Reform UK received a record £9m cash donation from crypto investor Christopher Harborne over the summer, making it the first UK party to accept crypto gifts even though this was in cash. Electoral Commission figures show Reform’s overall haul of just over £10m now exceeds the Conservatives’ £7m and Labour’s £2.5m. Harborne, an early Tether backer with defence and aviation‐fuel interests, previously funded Farage’s Brexit Party and Boris Johnson. Additional donations include £50k from Claudia Rothermere, £490k from ex‐Tory Nick Candy and £100k from tech billionaire Bassim Haidar. Campaigners including Transparency International and Spotlight on Corruption have renewed calls for caps on large political gifts.

articles.title: Peer suspended from House of Lords was allegedly paid $1m in ‘corrupt’ deal
articles.trailText: Lord Evans of Watford and other directors of investment firm deny claims made in lawsuits they say are ‘meritless’
articles.summary: Lord Evans of Watford, a Labour peer suspended for five months by the Lords watchdog after a Guardian sting exposed cash-for-access events, is now sued in UK and US courts over a 2023 sale of Jusan Technologies’ Kazakhstan assets. Claimant Yerbol Orynbayev—ex-deputy PM of Kazakhstan—alleges Evans and fellow directors pocketed at least $1m in a ‘corrupt’ deal that sold $1.6bn of assets for $75m, on top of salaries and bonuses. Evans denies the claims as meritless, arguing the sale reflected frozen, devalued assets. Cases contest valuations and director remuneration.

articles.title: Reform deputy leader dismisses claims of Farage’s past racism as new witnesses come forward
articles.trailText: Richard Tice says testimony by about two dozen people about party leader’s school days is ‘made-up twaddle’
articles.summary: Reform UK deputy leader Richard Tice has branded as “made-up twaddle” the testimony of around two dozen witnesses – including BAFTA-winning director Peter Ettedgui – alleging that Nigel Farage made racist and antisemitic remarks at Dulwich College in his teens, such as “Hitler was right” and “gas them”. Farage has denied direct racist abuse, attributing any comments to teen “banter”, while acknowledging imperfect memory. Reform’s poll lead fell from 29% to 25%, and critics, including Labour’s Anna Turley, call for apologies to alleged victims.

articles.title: Welsh Labour MSs accuse Starmer government of rolling back devolution
articles.trailText: More than third of party’s Senedd members write to PM, in move seen as further evidence of Labour decline in Wales
articles.summary: Eleven Labour Senedd members wrote to PM Keir Starmer accusing his government of being “deeply insensitive” or guilty of “constitutional outrage” by bypassing devolved powers via the Pride in Place town regeneration scheme. They warned failure to devolve justice, policing, rail, crown estate and Barnett formula reform amounted to rolling back devolution. Although unsigned by Welsh government ministers, the letter—backed by First Minister discussions—demands equality for Wales. The UK government defends targeted funding. Plaid, Liberal Democrats and Tories say the dispute exposes Labour’s crisis in Wales ahead of the 2026 Senedd election.

articles.title: Reform council leader accused of racism after alleged remarks about Sadiq Khan
articles.trailText: Ian Cooper allegedly called Khan ‘narcissistic Pakistani’ and made comments about lawyer Shola Mos-Shogbamimu
articles.summary: Ian Cooper, leader of Staffordshire county council for Reform UK, is under internal investigation after alleged social media posts calling London mayor Sadiq Khan a “narcissistic Pakistani,” urging lawyer Shola Mos-Shogbamimu to “F off back to Nigeria,” denouncing migrants as “intent on colonising the UK,” attacking David Lammy and diversity schemes, and defending a colleague’s racist critique of a statue. Previously Farage’s Tamworth candidate, Cooper’s remarks have been branded far-right and highlight vetting failures in Reform UK.

articles.title: Keir Starmer expected to award 25 new Labour peerages
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Former union bosses and Labour staffers on list as prime minister aims to balance chamber
articles.summary: Following last December’s creation of 30 peers, Prime Minister Keir Starmer will publish before Christmas a list of about 25 new Labour peerages to strengthen his party’s hand in the House of Lords. Expected nominees include former Usdaw general secretary Paddy Lillis, ex-chief of staff Katie Martin, outgoing communications director Matthew Doyle and veteran aide Carol Linforth. The appointments aim to counter Conservative and crossbench obstruction of renters’ rights, employment rights and assisted dying bills. Reform UK leader Nigel Farage’s peerage request was ignored. Lords leader Angela Smith will next year introduce mandatory retirement at 80 and participation requirements for peers.

articles.title: Reform UK aiming for reverse takeover of Tories, Farage says
articles.trailText: Leader says electoral deal now would cost his party votes but he aims to continue winning over defectors
articles.summary: Nigel Farage insists Reform UK seeks a "reverse takeover" of the Conservatives rather than a formal electoral pact, arguing any deal now would cost votes. He aims to absorb defectors — 21 ex-Tory MPs have already switched — and supplant the party. Labour has seized on this to portray an ideological merger, while donors and some Tory right-wingers privately discuss post-election pacts ranging from non-aggression agreements to coalitions. Kemi Badenoch rules out any alliance, and senior Tories debate shifting centrist leadership to survive.

articles.title: Keith McDowall obituary
articles.trailText: Journalist and PR consultant who worked for Conservative and Labour ministers and enjoyed ‘mingling’ with those in power
articles.summary: Keith McDowall, 96, was a journalist-turned-PR consultant who reshaped government communications. As chief information officer at the Home Office, then for Tory minister Willie Whitelaw in Northern Ireland (1972–74), he pioneered PR strategies and a confidential hotline. After serving Labour's Michael Foot on the Social Contract, he became MD of British Shipbuilders' information division, then CBI deputy director-general (1986–88). He coached future TUC leader and later wife Brenda Dean, earned a CBE before founding his consultancy (sold 1999). A memoirist and cross-party networker, McDowall also launched Kiss FM and chaired Natpro. He is survived by two daughters.

articles.title: Who will lose out when Labour cuts red tape? | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Deregulation danger | Your Party | Talking up pork | Nowhere Lane | Abattoir address
articles.summary: Five readers’ letters respond to a range of topics: Sally Bean from Weybridge critiques Keir Starmer’s drive to abolish ‘unnecessary’ regulation, urging a shift from market burdens to public protections (‘who is protected and from what?’); Deirdre Burrell highlights how 62% of members opposed naming ‘Your Party’ yet it prevailed, likening it to general election votes for losing parties; Robert Howard lauds pork crackling over beef savings; Tony Meacock notes Norfolk’s contradictory Nowhere Lane; Patricia Whittaker recalls a village abattoir once at Kilum Hall now replaced by a butcher’s shop.

articles.title: Spoilt for choice, Conspiracy Kemi grabs wrong end of every stick | John Crace
articles.trailText: After the budget there should have been easy wins for Badenoch at PMQs but the Tory leader just can’t help herself
articles.summary: At PMQs following the budget, Tory leader Kemi Badenoch bypassed obvious attacks—Labour’s alleged tax freezes and phantom income tax rises—to peddle wild conspiracy theories: dark forces pushing OBR chair Richard Hughes out, shadowy market manipulation by civil servants and the chancellor’s purported 2p tax hike. She demanded multiple resignations from her own party and Labour, contradicted by facts, as her backbenchers looked on in embarrassment. Sir Keir Starmer largely stayed silent, letting her self-inflicted chaos undercut her performance. The article portrays Badenoch as overexcitable and misguided, mishandling what should have been a straightforward assault on Labour’s fiscal record and deepening Tory divisions.

articles.title: Mark Fisher obituary
articles.trailText: Popular and energetic Labour MP who served for a year as arts minister in Tony Blair’s government
articles.summary: Labour MP Mark Fisher, who died aged 81, was a popular Stoke-on-Trent Central representative for 27 years and served briefly (1997–98) as Blair’s arts minister, helping shape the Cool Britannia agenda before his uncompromising idealism led to his removal. A lifelong left-winger, he championed the precursor to the Freedom of Information Act, chaired party arts committees and published plays, poetry and reports on cities and culture. Son of Conservative MP Sir Nigel Fisher, he was educated at Eton and Cambridge, worked as a film producer and education principal, married twice and left a wife, two children and two stepchildren.

articles.title: Foreign Office lost ‘opportunities to influence’ US after Harry Dunn death, review finds
articles.trailText: Anne Owers highlights delays in escalation after crash in August 2019, after which Anne Sacoolas flew to US
articles.summary: An independent review by Dame Anne Owers found the Foreign Office failed to escalate and engage early after US diplomat’s wife Anne Sacoolas killed 19-year-old Harry Dunn in August 2019 at RAF Croughton. Ministers and senior officials were not involved, direct family communication was late and sporadic, and FO officials missed opportunities to challenge the US claim that diplomatic immunity exempted Sacoolas despite a waiver. Sacoolas was allowed to return to the US days later, with police and the Dunn family informed only weeks afterwards. The report criticises a botched family meeting, eroded trust, and calls for reforms.

articles.title: Farage tells donors he expects Reform to do election deal with Tories – report
articles.trailText: One donor tells FT that Reform leader described an agreement as ‘inevitable’, despite denials from both sides
articles.summary: Nigel Farage privately told Reform UK donors he sees a merger or electoral pact with the Conservatives before the next general election as ‘inevitable’, though he insists on a ‘reverse takeover’ and professes distrust in the Tories. Both he and Tory leadership, including Kemi Badenoch, deny deal plans, warning Reform favors higher welfare spending and ties with Putin. Despite Reform’s polling surge and MP defections like Jonathan Gullis, Conservatives attracted £6.3m in donations versus Reform’s £2.1m. Labour accuses Farage of courting ‘failed Tories’ and warns any alliance risks renewed austerity cuts to schools and hospitals.

articles.title: Key aide to Nigel Farage was frontman for Premier League billionaire’s betting syndicate, lawsuit claims
articles.trailText: Exclusive: George Cottrell ‘gave control’ of gambling accounts to syndicate headed by Tony Bloom, the owner of Brighton & Hove Albion FC
articles.summary: High court papers allege George Cottrell, a senior Reform UK aide and former wire-fraud convict, was a 'whale' frontman for Tony Bloom’s Starlizard Betting Syndicate, placing £600m-a-year football bets via his secret Stake.com accounts from Canary Wharf. Bloom – Brighton & Hove Albion’s billionaire owner – supposedly covered Cottrell’s losses in return for a 33% share of wins. Ex-associate Ryan Dudfield is suing over an estimated $250m pot, claiming he’s owed $17.5m after syndicate bets continued despite assurances of termination. Bloom has yet to file a defence.

articles.title: Lammy’s jury trial plans are ‘massive mistake’, say Labour MPs and peers
articles.trailText: Only cases such as murder and rape or offences carrying sentence longer than three years would face jury under plans
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy proposes to end jury trials in ‘either-way’ offences with likely sentences under three years, reserve them for murder, rape and offences over three years, extend magistrates’ sentencing powers from one to 18 months (up to 24), and create judge-only “swift” courts. Labour MPs and peers warn the cuts (5,000–7,500 fewer jury trials) risk miscarriages for working-class, women and minority defendants, won’t clear backlogs and erode public trust. Critics cite Leveson review alignment, compare to authoritarian reforms, and doubt parliamentary passage.

articles.title: Lack of apology for schoolboy ‘banter’ speaks volumes about Nigel Farage | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: When a public figure responds with denial instead of a ‘sorry’, we should heed what that tells us, Anthony Richards . Plus letters from other readers on how being bullied at school affected them their whole life
articles.summary: Following Peter Ettedgui’s account of antisemitic taunts by Nigel Farage as a teen, letter writers including Anthony Richards, Kirsty Pierce, Barry Neville and Keith Mason critique Farage’s denial and failure to apologise. Richards stresses that trauma anchors memories and that a simple “sorry” demonstrates accountability and empathy. Correspondents recount vivid school days in 1970s convent and private schools—taunted for being Jewish, overweight or for their appearance—arguing that genuine contrition offers closure, while Farage’s minimisation and insistence on misremembered “banter” perpetuates harm and reveals his character to the public. They reject his assertion that decades render memories unreliable, emphasizing the durability of school trauma.

articles.title: Is David Lammy persuaded by his own jury trials proposal? Not sure. But he said it anyway | John Crace
articles.trailText: Investment was not enough to save the courts, said the justice secretary. At least, not the amounts he was prepared to put in
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy, once foreign secretary, proposed judge-only trials for offences carrying up to three years and extended magistrates’ sentencing to 18 months to tackle a 78,000-case backlog he blamed on underinvestment. Invoking Magna Carta’s ‘justice delayed is justice denied’, he argued this would favour victims and increase transparency, yet sceptics in his own party and Labour’s shadow team warned of increased miscarriages of justice and authoritarian drift. Critics like Diane Abbott and backbenchers urged temporary reforms and proper funding instead.

articles.title: UK ministers aim to ban cryptocurrency political donations over anonymity risks
articles.trailText: Crackdown, which will be blow to Nigel Farage’s Reform party, not likely to be ready for elections bill in new year
articles.summary: Whitehall sources say UK ministers plan to outlaw cryptocurrency donations, citing unverifiable sources that threaten electoral integrity, but the ban likely won’t feature in the next elections bill due early 2025, which focuses on lowering the voting age and closing finance loopholes. The move targets Reform UK—the first party to accept crypto, via its own portal—and follows growing concern among officials and the Electoral Commission over tracing wallet ownership, especially abroad. While earlier guidance treated crypto as an assessable asset, watchdog chief Vijay Rangarajan remains sceptical about manual tracking costs. Campaigners urge criminal sanctions to block foreign meddling.

articles.title: David Lammy tells of ‘traumatic’ racial abuse in youth after Farage allegations
articles.trailText: Deputy PM contrasts apologies from former classmates to Reform UK leader’s response to claims against him
articles.summary: Deputy PM David Lammy described his own school-era racial abuse as “traumatic” and urged Reform UK leader Nigel Farage to apologize for alleged racist and antisemitic comments made as a teenager. More than 20 former Dulwich College classmates, including director Peter Ettedgui, have recounted Farage using slurs, praising Hitler and targeting minority pupils. Farage denies direct racism, calling testimonies politically motivated. Keir Starmer, Attorney General Richard Hermer and London Mayor Sadiq Khan have criticized his denials and demanded contrition.

articles.title: Angela Rayner to lay amendment to speed up workers’ rights bill
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Former deputy PM understood to have accepted compromise on day-one rights, after ‘considerable anger’ over Lords intervention
articles.summary: Angela Rayner will table an amendment to accelerate the Workers’ Rights Bill, reinstating a six-month qualifying period for unfair dismissal by early 2026, after Lords rejected day-one rights. The compromise replaces two years, secures removal of compensation caps and extends rights to zero-hours and variable-contract staff, with penalties for employers who block union access. Rayner and Justin Madders aim to sidestep lengthy consultations, rally Labour MPs determined to prevent further watering down and deliver faster, tangible workplace protections a year earlier than planned.

articles.title: UK terror watchdog warns national security plan ignores escalating online threats
articles.trailText: Independent reviewer says need to protect against online threats is now as important as need for robust armed forces
articles.summary: Jonathan Hall KC, the UK’s independent terrorism laws reviewer, warns the 2025 national security strategy omits online threats, despite digital channels now equalling air, sea and land forces as vectors for terrorism and hostile state action. He cites extremist content on Roblox, a chatbot incitement to attack Windsor, and Wagner group recruitment for arson. Hall criticises the Online Safety Act’s lack of removal powers, urges clearer mandates for tech platforms, and calls for updating pre-digital surveillance laws to let counter-terrorism authorities use publicly available online data. Ofcom is probing social media compliance; the government maintains its framework is robust.

articles.title: Attorney general urges Nigel Farage to apologise over alleged racism and antisemitism
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Richard Hermer, a senior Jewish minister, says Reform leader ‘clearly deeply hurt’ many people with his alleged behaviour
articles.summary: Attorney general Richard Hermer, a senior Jewish minister, has urged Reform UK leader Nigel Farage to apologise to former Dulwich College classmates who allege he racially abused them between ages 13 and 18, chanting “Hitler was right” and targeting minority pupils. More than 20 individuals have now shared similar accounts. Farage denies direct racism or antisemitism and calls past remarks “banter.” Hermer, backed by Labour’s Keir Starmer and Chancellor Rachel Reeves, says his changing denials are unconvincing and calls a prompt apology essential if Farage seeks credibility as prime minister.

articles.title: Starmer has little choice but to bind himself closer to his chancellor
articles.trailText: Ditching Rachel Reeves would put spotlight back on real context for decision to drop idea of breaching manifesto
articles.summary: Amid Tory calls to sack Chancellor Rachel Reeves over tax forecasts and a leaked OBR budget, Keir Starmer publicly reinforced his loyalty, admitting he alone considered breaching Labour’s manifesto by raising income tax but decided against it. Facing OBR chair Richard Hughes’s resignation and briefings exposing spin on fiscal forecasts, Starmer defended Reeves at a Southwark press conference, framing budget choices as his own. Yet restive, economically minded Labour MPs fear this self-preserving, unambitious spending plan weakens living standards and risks internal rebellion.

articles.title: Your Party faces proxy war despite avoiding leadership race, insiders warn
articles.trailText: Some members say supporters of Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana will continue battle over ‘soul of the party’
articles.summary: Your Party’s inaugural conference approved a 16-member collective leadership over a direct contest between Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana, but insiders warn supporters of both figures will continue a ‘proxy war’ over the party’s direction. Sultana boycotted day one after some backers faced expulsion for dual memberships. Tensions persist over executive dominance fears—sources say a Sultana-leaning board could prompt MP resignations—though others hail the model as a de-escalation. Members also endorsed a ‘targeted’ electoral strategy in key seats and signalled openness to local Greens alliances.

articles.title: Why it’s silly to focus on Labour’s manifesto pledges | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Manifestos are not binding contracts – good politics is about being able to react to circumstances, says Tony Wright
articles.summary: Tony Wright argues Labour’s vow not to raise main revenue-raising taxes was irresponsible and needless, as victory was assured by anti-Tory sentiment. He says manifestos should serve as broad prospectuses reflecting potential economic shifts, not binding contracts. Voters grant a mandate to govern, requiring adaptation to new challenges. Wright insists that reversing or replacing a bad policy with a better one—often labeled a U-turn—is actually a mark of good government, not political weakness.

articles.title: Does Labour have a death wish or does it secretly enjoy the agony of self-sabotage?
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer may be keen to move on from the budget megashambles, but chaos is hardwired into his party
articles.summary: John Crace argues Labour’s chronic disarray—freebie promises, benefit‐cuts U-turns and a botched budget full of leaks, reversals and timeline confusion—is less incompetence than deliberate self-sabotage. Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves failed to control the narrative, handing the Tories ammunition to accuse them of market manipulation and fiscal recklessness. Starmer’s belated reframing of the budget as a moral mission—ending the two-child benefit cap, boosting productivity, funding public services and a pragmatic EU-style customs union—attempts to reset the debate but exposed Labour’s internal angst.

articles.title: Labour’s economic plan will take years to deliver, Keir Starmer says
articles.trailText: Exclusive: PM hits back at critics as he insists Rachel Reeves right to impose £26bn worth of tax rises at budget
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer defended Rachel Reeves’s £26bn tax rises and unveiled a multiyear economic roadmap to be judged at the next election, promising infrastructure deregulation, a welfare overhaul targeting mental health and disability support, and closer European ties. He rejected both austerity and debt-driven quick fixes, accusing hardliners on left and right of courting decline. After markets welcomed the budget’s fiscal tightening, Conservatives demanded Reeves’s resignation over alleged OBR forecast misrepresentation; Labour counters that projections shift until final cycles. Post-budget polling shows 60% still view the chancellor’s performance negatively. Starmer will elaborate this long-term renewal plan in a Monday speech.

articles.title: Your Party members vote to make name permanent at tense first conference
articles.trailText: Liverpool gathering lays bare bitter divisions within new party founded by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana
articles.summary: At its inaugural Liverpool conference, members of the new leftwing party founded by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana narrowly voted (37%) to make “Your Party” its permanent name (vs Popular Alliance 25.23%, For The Many 23.52%, Our Party 14.19%). A slim majority (51.6%) backed a member-led executive over Corbyn’s sole-leader model, with a review of leadership options due before the next election. Tensions flared over expulsions of Socialist Workers Party affiliates, approval of dual membership (69.2%), anti-Zionism calls and factional purges, as Sultana and Corbyn traded barbs amid threats of further splits.

articles.title: Shabana Mahmood and my surprise at teenagers’ views on immigration | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Rev Dr Michael Fox responds to an article by Nesrine Malik on the home secretary using her ‘story’ to silence criticism of her policies
articles.summary: In this letter Rev Dr Michael Fox responds to Nesrine Malik’s critique of Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood’s immigration narrative, arguing her personal story is used to deflect policy criticism. Recalling a 2005 OU documentary interview with 15-year-olds in Manchester, he notes second-generation immigrant teens voiced restrictive ‘the country is full’ views—driven by ‘self-othering’—while white British peers embraced newcomers. Fox contrasts modern ‘drawbridge’ Tory Home Secretaries with Robert Carr’s 1972 compassion in admitting Ugandan refugees.

articles.title: Let’s not repeat the folly of PFIs for NHS buildings | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: PFI contracts tend to be led by building contractors rather than architects, and too often savings in costs and time are at the expense of design, materials, and with high finance and safety, writes Martin Cook
articles.summary: Chartered architect and retired barrister Martin Cook warns against re-adopting private finance initiatives for NHS buildings after independent UK audit reviews exposed a consistent “quality gap” versus traditional design-led procurement. PFI contracts, he argues, are driven by building contractors at the expense of architectural oversight, resulting in poor functionality, short-life materials, safety non-compliance and inflated financing and support charges. As 25–30-year concessions end, neglected maintenance and dilapidated hand-backs exacerbate long-term costs, proving PFI is not a viable procurement model.

articles.title: Fears for UK security as Foreign Office moves to scrap unit on conflict and refugee crises
articles.trailText: MPs warn axing FCDO’s migration and conflict directorate amid staff cuts risks undermining peace work and expertise
articles.summary: Facing real-terms budget cuts after aid spending falls to 0.3%, the FCDO will abolish its 100-person migration and conflict directorate, subsuming its Syria, South Sudan, Ethiopia, Yemen and Philippines peacebuilding work into other units. MPs and APPG chairs warn the move risks undermining UK security, conflict prevention and refugee support, urging ministers to pause cuts. Labour’s Sarah Champion and the PCS union dispute a lack of consultation. The FCDO defends its restructure as modernisation, promising continued focus on migration and conflict priorities. Permanent secretary Oliver Robbins said cuts reflect aid reduction decisions, while the PCS union has lodged a dispute over consultation.

articles.title: Your Party to have ‘collective leadership’ in win for Zarah Sultana
articles.trailText: Members vote narrowly in favour at founding conference overshadowed by Sultana’s rift with Jeremy Corbyn
articles.summary: At its Liverpool founding conference, the new left-wing ‘Your Party’ narrowly approved a collective leadership model by 51.6% to 48.4%, a victory for former Labour MP Zarah Sultana, who clashed with co-founder Jeremy Corbyn over decision-making. The party will be governed by a member-led executive with a chair, deputy and spokesperson, and allow dual membership of other aligned groups pending executive ratification. Conference drama, including Sultana’s boycott and the expulsion of delegates, underscored internal fractures amid competition with the resurging Greens.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves denies lying to public in run-up to budget
articles.trailText: Chancellor accused of misleading public about reasons for tax rises, with opposition politicians calling for her resignation
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves rejects claims she misled public over record £26bn tax rises in last week’s budget, arguing she boosted fiscal “headroom” from £9.9bn to £21.7bn to safeguard spending and economic resilience. Despite OBR saying strong wage growth and tax receipts offset its productivity downgrade, critics led by Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch accuse her of abandoning manifesto pledges and exaggerating forecasts, demanding her resignation. PM Starmer will defend her, touting the budget’s impact on cost-of-living and inflation and unveiling business deregulation, nuclear power reform, and infrastructure measures.

articles.title: Your Party’s first conference shows little sign of achieving fresh start
articles.trailText: Differences between Zarah Sultana and Jeremy Corbyn and over admitting Socialist Workers members mean rows look likely to continue
articles.summary: At its inaugural conference in Liverpool, cofounders Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana clashed over leadership and membership rules, undermining hopes of unity in the new leftwing Your Party. Corbyn backed a traditional single leader model and hinted at running himself, while Sultana championed collective leadership and condemned a toxic culture, intimidation and witch-hunt expulsions of Socialist Workers members. She boycotted day one in solidarity with excluded delegates, prompting Corbyn allies to denounce her stance as a disruptive sideshow. Delegates, largely disillusioned ex-Labour members, lamented that infighting overshadowed debates on cost of living and local election strategy. Key votes on name and governance loom.

articles.title: Your Party conference thrown into chaos as Zarah Sultana boycotts first day
articles.trailText: Sultana skips Saturday’s proceeding in solidarity with delegates expelled over links to other parties
articles.summary: At Your Party’s inaugural conference in Liverpool, co-founder Zarah Sultana skipped day one in protest after delegates were expelled over alleged Socialist Workers Party links and to oppose Jeremy Corbyn’s push for a sole leadership, advocating collective leadership and maximum member democracy. Corbyn, who will likely stand as single leader, said he would accept members’ choice. Sultana will run if a sole model is chosen. The row underscores deep infighting over governance, membership rules and culture, though both signal willingness to cooperate with Greens and other left groups. She also drew criticism by launching a membership portal that raised around £800,000.

articles.title: Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana’s Your Party reveals shortlist for official name
articles.trailText: Leftwing party asks members to pick between Your Party, Our Party, Popular Alliance and For The Many
articles.summary: The leftwing party co-founded by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana, temporarily dubbed Your Party, has shortlisted four names—Your Party, Our Party, Popular Alliance and For The Many—for its 50,000 members to vote on at a first conference in Liverpool. Some 2,500 attendees chosen via lottery will debate party structures, programme, leadership model (single versus collective) and proposals to back socialist independents in 2026 local elections. The group has endured resignations (Iqbal Mohamed, Adnan Hussain), infighting over finances and launch strategy, and cancellations of memberships tied to other left parties. Speeches from MPs, grassroots organizers and European left figures will seek to cement a mass, member-led democratic socialist movement, Sultana says, backed by the Socialist Unity Platform.

articles.title: Former Ukip MEP denies taking money to promote Russian interests
articles.trailText: David Coburn, who was leader of Ukip in Scotland, denies involvement after Nathan Gill jailed for taking bribes
articles.summary: David Coburn, leader of Ukip Scotland (2014–19) and former Ukip/Brexit Party MEP, denies ever taking payments to promote Russian interests after ex-colleague Nathan Gill was jailed for 10½ years for accepting bribes from alleged pro-Russian asset Oleg Voloshyn, working for Viktor Medvedchuk. WhatsApp exchanges in Gill’s prosecution reveal a $6.5k allocation “for David” ahead of a 112 Ukraine editorial board meeting in April 2019. Coburn hasn’t been charged and maintains his innocence, while fellow former Ukip MEP Jonathan Arnott also denies any Russian links.

articles.title: Woman jailed for harassing Rachel Reeves’s MP sister
articles.trailText: Tracey Smith sent the government minister and MP Ellie Reeves 22 emails and 10 voicemails
articles.summary: Tracey Smith, 58, was jailed for 26 weeks and ordered to pay £650 after harassing solicitor general MP Ellie Reeves with 22 emails and 10 voicemails accusing her of transphobia, legalising sexual abuse and alleging assault by Reeves’s sister, Chancellor Rachel Reeves. Between July and October 2024 Smith, a trans woman, threatened “bullets will be flying” and obtained a witness summons that Reeves overturned via Commons lawyers, leading to an indefinite restraining order. Judge Michael Snow described the campaign as a deliberate attack on democracy that caused Reeves significant anxiety, lifestyle changes and the need for special protection.

articles.title: Labour MPs to demand more concessions on workers’ rights after government climbdown
articles.trailText: Unhappy MPs will push for stronger protections in other areas, such as bogus self-employment arrangements
articles.summary: Labour backbenchers including Andy McDonald, Neil Duncan-Jordan and Rachael Maskell will push for stronger protections—particularly a crackdown on bogus self-employment—after ministers dropped plans for day-one unfair dismissal rights. The government’s amended employment bill now guarantees that right after six months’ service, while preserving day-one paternity leave and sick pay from April 2026. Negotiated in secret talks with unions and brokered by business secretary Peter Kyle, the deal also lifts the compensation cap. Angela Rayner, who led the legislation, won’t rebel to ensure a pre-Christmas Commons vote.

articles.title: Only people power can save us from populism | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Democratic safeguards won’t work unless they’re backed by the will of the people, argues Peter Loschi , while Roger Heppleston calls for wholesale reform of the British political system. Plus letters from Rob Hunter , Peter Buckman and Dr Piers Brendon
articles.summary: Correspondents argue that democratic safeguards only work if citizens actively uphold them. Peter Loschi warns that Enlightenment checks fail without public will and proposes replacing the House of Lords with a six-monthly citizens’ assembly whose successive approvals would block extremist measures like abolishing judicial independence. Roger Heppleston calls for a complete overhaul of Britain’s short-term, charisma-driven system to restore vision and expertise. Rob Hunter urges embedding student participation in schools to cultivate democratic values. Peter Buckman demands a powerful independent accountability office to enforce manifesto promises, while Piers Brendon questions monarchy as a democratic bulwark.

articles.title: A public inquiry on Brexit might make it easier for us to rejoin the EU | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Let’s set the record straight on the cause of our economic woes and inability to control immigration, writes Robert Gildea . Plus a letter from Rachel Foggitt
articles.summary: Robert Gildea calls on Labour to commission a public Brexit inquiry, blame Nigel Farage for economic stagnation and immigration chaos, noting 57% of voters would rejoin the EU, and proposes a BBC 10th-anniversary series to build momentum. Rachel Foggitt contends the UK can afford robust public services if it fairly taxes the ultra-wealthy, arguing that ‘tough choices’ currently penalize the poorest. Both writers urge accountability: one to pave the way back into Europe, the other to redistribute wealth through fair taxation.

articles.title: The Green party’s policies on Israel are appealing to young British Jews | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Prof David Feldman, Dr Ben Gidley and Dr Brendan McGeever from the Birkbeck Institute for the Study of Antisemitism say it is wrong to characterise Jewish support for the Greens as ‘paradoxical’
articles.summary: Prof David Feldman, Dr Ben Gidley and Dr Brendan McGeever challenge the notion that Jewish support for the Green party is "paradoxical," drawing on JPR data showing Jewish backing for Greens has surged 900% relative to the party’s overall growth. They highlight that 22% of 16–29-year-olds and 19% of 30–49-year-olds, alongside 25% of non-Zionist and 62% of anti-Zionist Jews, now support Greens. This trend, they argue, reflects attraction to Green policies on Israel rather than indifference to foreign affairs, underlining the diversity of Jewish political identity beyond Labour and Conservative allegiances.

articles.title: Sadiq Khan recalls past abuse as he urges Nigel Farage to apologise over racism claims
articles.trailText: Exclusive: London mayor says allegations of teenage racism against Reform leader remind him of being called P-word
articles.summary: London mayor Sadiq Khan has urged Reform leader Nigel Farage to apologise after more than 20 former classmates accused him of racist and antisemitic slurs at Dulwich College between ages 13 and 18. Khan, recalling his own experience being called the “P-word,” said Farage’s dismissal of the allegations as playground “banter” fails to acknowledge their lasting harm. Farage has categorically denied the claims but later conceded he might have made ill-judged remarks. Khan and other senior figures, including Prime Minister Keir Starmer, stress the need to confront racism’s enduring impact.

articles.title: Budget has preserved Starmer’s job until at least May elections, say Labour MPs
articles.trailText: While some call budget ‘tactical victory’, few MPs believe it is enough for Labour to beat Reform
articles.summary: Labour MPs say Keir Starmer’s job is secure until May’s elections after a cautious budget that avoided risks but won’t shift fundamentals enough to overtake Reform. Although touted as a ‘tactical victory’—favoured by bond markets and backbenchers—it leaves voters’ living standards squeezed. Rachel Reeves’ ‘love-bombing’ of MPs and Morgan McSweeney’s post-budget peace mission paper over factional tensions, while Wes Streeting’s soft-left alliances fuel leadership speculation. With local elections looming, No 10 is plotting narrative wins in key council contests to offset expected losses in Wales, Scotland and England.

articles.title: Labour MPs attack Starmer U-turn over workers’ rights as ‘complete betrayal’
articles.trailText: Former minister says ditching plan for day-one protection against unfair dismissal ‘definitely is a manifesto breach’
articles.summary: Labour MPs including Andy McDonald, Neil Duncan-Jordan and Rachael Maskell have condemned Keir Starmer’s decision to abandon day-one protection against unfair dismissal—promised in the manifesto—in favour of a six-month qualifying period. The U-turn, aimed at speeding passage of the employment rights bill (which still guarantees day-one sick pay and parental leave from April 2026), was branded a “complete betrayal” by ex-minister Justin Madders. Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson argued the change was needed to avoid delays and allow full consultation with businesses and unions.

articles.title: UK rejects visa for girl left destitute in Jamaica by Hurricane Melissa
articles.trailText: Lati-Yana Brown’s parents had asked for application to be expedited so she could join them in UK after house ruined
articles.summary: Eight-year-old Lati-Yana Stephanie Brown, left destitute when Hurricane Melissa destroyed her home in Cash Hill, Jamaica, has had her UK visa application refused despite her British father and Jamaican-born mother urging an expedited decision. After paying the £4,000 fee in June, parents Kerrian Bigby and Jerome Hardy warned the hurricane created an emergency, with Brown’s grandmother unable to care for her, yet the Home Office ruled no evidence she lacks family care locally. The family will appeal amid a 106,000-case backlog. Lawyer Naga Kandiah decried the decision as lacking compassion, and Unicef has launched a regional child aid appeal.

articles.title: ‘We had six MPs and four factions’: inside Your Party’s toxic power struggles
articles.trailText: Some say Jeremy Corbyn is too non-committal for project to work, while others blame Zarah Sultana’s combative nature
articles.summary: Your Party, launched by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana with six MPs and four factions, has been crippled by internal feuds. A July 3 split saw Sultana abruptly declare co-leadership, blindsiding an indecisive Corbyn and sparking a WhatsApp war. Later, Sultana’s solo membership drive—raising £800,000 on her own software—prompted Corbyn allies to lock her out and refer the matter to the ICO. Two MPs quit, decrying a ‘toxic, exclusionary’ culture. Now 3,000 members descend on Liverpool to settle leadership, balance Corbyn’s caution against Sultana’s combative style, and salvage a movement rivaling Labour and the Greens.

articles.title: Peter Mandelson’s lobbying firm hired by company linked to Chinese military
articles.trailText: Global Counsel signed $3m contract with WuXi AppTec in Europe months after it was named in US national security drive
articles.summary: Global Counsel, co-founded by Peter Mandelson, signed a $3m deal in May 2024 to advise Chinese pharma WuXi AppTec on European geopolitical risk mitigation after US biosecurity scrutiny over alleged military and Xinjiang human rights links. The firm limited work to EU policy and declared the contract in the EU register. Mandelson stepped down in Dec 2024, retaining a ring-fenced minority stake. US Biosecure Act proposals targeting ‘adversary biotech’ failed in the Senate; a revised bill passed later. WuXi plans its first European HQ in Germany.

articles.title: ‘Unelected power’ of ultra-rich is reshaping British politics, report claims
articles.trailText: Equality Trust study shows how House of Lords appointments, big donations and media ownership affect political decisions
articles.summary: The Equality Trust’s report Money, Media and Lords warns that unelected influence in UK politics has surged alongside wealth concentration in the top 1%. Since 2005 House of Lords appointees rose from 676 to 803, political donations over £250,000 climbed from £7.6m to £47m+, and the three biggest news groups now control 90% of national newspaper circulation (up from 71%). Combined Google and Meta dominate 60% of ad spend and 93% of search. It calls for a £5,000 cap on private donations, curbs on appointments, ownership diversity mandates, and investment in independent local media.

articles.title: Keir Starmer says Labour ‘kept to our manifesto’ over budget tax rises
articles.trailText: PM seeks to rebuff claims government broke its promises while conceding budget ‘asked everybody to contribute’
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer insisted Labour’s £26bn tax rises – including a three-year freeze on income tax and national insurance thresholds – honoured its manifesto, arguing these “fair” contributions protect the NHS, fund schools and curb living costs. He defended scrapping the two-child benefit cap to lift 450,000 children out of poverty. Chancellor Rachel Reeves said she’d minimised the impact on working households by targeting betting firms, landlords and high-value homes while vowing to defy OBR forecasts and drive growth.

articles.title: Is Farage right to claim that racism allegations are response to a dislike of his politics?
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader has again denied allegations about his behaviour as a schoolboy but what are the facts?
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage has denied schoolboy racism allegations, attributing them to opponents of his politics. At a press conference—excluding Guardian questions—he apologized if anyone was hurt but insisted he never used racial or antisemitic slurs. However, Peter Ettedgui and at least seven other contemporaries, including Jewish and BAME classmates and a former teacher, testify Farage repeatedly taunted them with phrases like "Hitler was right", "gas them", "stupid yid" and other slurs. Over 20 witnesses have now come forward, most politically uninvolved, refuting his claim that allegations stem from political bias. Farage’s citation of unrelated figure Roger Gough does not align with the Guardian’s verified sources.

articles.title: OBR’s leak was the only leak Reeves wasn’t responsible for in pre-budget shambles
articles.trailText: Chancellor tried a different approach to this budget, revealing all her plans and causing chaos before she even delivered it
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves intentionally leaked and reversed key measures pre-budget to dissipate criticism, culminating in a genuine leak by the OBR 90 minutes before PMQs. Despite a chaotic rollout—abandoned 2p tax rise, pre-announced policies and flat delivery—market reaction was calm. Kemi Badenoch’s opposition speech floundered in the chamber, overshadowed by press and a dog, while fiscal watchdogs’ assessments now define the budget’s fate.

articles.title: Starmer calls on Farage to apologise to his alleged victims of racial abuse at school
articles.trailText: Prime minister says Reform leader’s explanations about alleged comments are ‘unconvincing to say the least’
articles.summary: At PMQs, Keir Starmer urged Nigel Farage to apologise to Dulwich College classmates who say he racially abused them at age 13, growling ‘Hitler was right’ and mimicking gas-chamber hisses. Peter Ettedgui, now an Emmy-winning director, and six others have corroborated the testimony. Farage has alternately denied any intent or involvement, then offered a conditional apology to anyone hurt. Starmer called these shifting explanations ‘unconvincing to say the least.’

articles.title: Racism claims against Nigel Farage are no surprise to us | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers describe the ubiquity of racist attitudes and behaviours at British public schools at the time the Reform UK leader attended Dulwich College
articles.summary: Ex-pupils of British public schools contemporary with Nigel Farage at Dulwich College report that overt racism—slurs against Jewish, Indian, Pakistani, African and Muslim students—was routine and dismissed by teachers as mere ‘naughtiness.’ They recall quotas capping Jewish admissions, public humiliation of a Muslim classmate, and a mock 1979 ballot celebrating the National Front with applause for speakers like Enoch Powell and Patrick Moore. These elite institutions, designed to forge imperial cadres, imparted swagger and entitlement alongside prejudice, explaining why claims of Farage’s teenage racism come as no surprise and warning that unchanged schools will keep producing more figures like him.

articles.title: Hereditary peers aren’t out of touch with the realities of the job market | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Nicholas True responds to an article that reported that hereditary peers had voted against Labour’s employment bill
articles.summary: Nicholas True, Leader of the Opposition in the House of Lords, rebuts claims that hereditary peers blocking Labour’s employment bill are ‘out of touch’. He highlights peers’ extensive business experience, notes UK unemployment at 5% (1.7m on benefits) and warns the bill would cost firms £5bn annually. He cites support from the FSB, CBI, IoD, Make UK, Care England and Sir Tony Blair, and argues the legislation would have been defeated by over 100 votes even without hereditary peers, backed by Conservative, Liberal Democrat, Unionist and crossbench peers, while fewer than two-thirds of Labour peers supported it.

articles.title: Reeves freezes fuel duty for now as she confirms 3p-a-mile electric vehicle charge
articles.trailText: Rishi Sunak’s ‘temporary’ 5p-a-litre cut to be reversed in stages from next September in effort to keep EVs attractive
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves has frozen fuel duty at 52.95p a litre until September 2026, reversing the temporary 5p-a-litre cut from next autumn with staged increases thereafter, a move the OBR says costs £2.4bn next year and £900m annually. From 2028, a new pay-per-mile EV levy—3p per mile for pure electric cars and 1.5p for plug-in hybrids—will raise £1.1bn in 2028–29 (rising to £1.9bn by 2030–31) but could reduce EV sales by about 24,000 a year. Reeves also doubled EV grants, raised the £50k luxury car threshold, and accelerated charging rollout.

articles.title: Three more ex-pupils at school with Nigel Farage reject ‘banter’ claims
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Dulwich college contemporaries ‘rubbish’ Reform UK leader’s suggestion alleged racist taunts not intended to hurt
articles.summary: Three ex-pupils from Dulwich College who witnessed Nigel Farage’s teenage racist and antisemitic taunts have rejected his claim that it was innocent “banter,” describing the abuse as targeted, persistent and hurtful. Stefan Benarroch, Cyrus Oshidar and Rickard Berg recounted ridicule aimed at Jewish classmates emerging from assemblies—among them Emmy-winning director Peter Ettedgui—and branded Farage’s denials “rubbish” and “lying.” They form part of over 20 contemporaries who allege he led six years of racial slurs starting at age 13. Farage has shifted his stance, admitting playground jibes but denying any intent to wound. They insist the conduct was deliberate.

articles.title: ‘Where’s Nige?’ Reform leader skips Commons statement on Ukraine, leaving Tice to face pile-on | John Crace
articles.trailText: With one of his old muckers from the EU days jailed for taking Russian bribes, there was no better time for Farage to absent himself
articles.summary: In the House of Commons, Reform UK leader Nigel Farage boycotted Keir Starmer’s statement on the G20 summit and Ukraine peace process, leaving Richard Tice alone to defend the party against a cross-party “pile-on.” Farage’s absence underscores his long record of pro-Russian remarks—he blamed Ukraine for the 2014 Crimea invasion—and his muted response to former MEP Nathan Gill’s conviction for taking Russian bribes. MPs including Kemi Badenoch and Starmer condemned Reform’s Kremlin-friendly posture and its refusal to investigate other bribery allegations, questioning the party’s commitment to Ukraine.

articles.title: ‘I didn’t start it’: Starmer apologises for ‘six seven’ uproar during school visit
articles.trailText: Prime minister jokes that he may be ‘put in detention’ after appearing to encourage classroom hysterics
articles.summary: During a visit to Welland Academy in Peterborough, PM Keir Starmer joined pupils chanting “six seven” after a student said she was on “page six-seven.” Encouraged by the viral dance craze tied to Skrilla’s Doot Doot (6 7) and LaMelo Ball clips, Starmer performed the move before being playfully scolded by headteacher Jo Anderson and apologising, quipping “I didn’t start it, Miss.” Accompanied by Education Secretary Bridget Phillipson, the PM joked he might be “put in detention” for fueling the TikTok trend blamed on parents’ and teachers’ irritation.

articles.title: How Lord Dannatt used his peerage to open doors for business interests
articles.trailText: Former head of British army is suspended from the House of Lords after being filmed breaking rules
articles.summary: Former army chief Lord Richard Dannatt leveraged his 2011 peerage and Tower of London constable role to lobby ministers and officials on behalf of commercial clients – from Sierra Leone’s Joule Africa (£500m hydro project) to US defence firm Teledyne and a UK fertiliser consortium – accepting gifts, shares and £8,000 in honorariums. A House of Lords inquiry found four rule breaches since 2022, ruling he improperly offered paid lobbying, and suspended him for four months for violating the code of conduct.

articles.title: Reform’s ‘Trumpian’ legal threats hint at more aggressive approach to media
articles.trailText: Ultimatums sent to publications appear to intensify as Nigel Farage’s party rises in polls
articles.summary: Nation.Cymru editor Mark Mansfield says Reform UK barrister Adam Richardson threatened legal action over "misuse of private information" and breach of confidence, giving two days to remove head of communications Ed Sumner’s name from a story on racist WhatsApp messages by Senedd member Laura Anne Jones or face damages. Richardson, who also represents Reform nationally, cited precedents including Naomi Campbell’s privacy case. Mansfield refused, calling the ultimatum "Trumpian" bullying. Similar threats have targeted Nottingham Post, the Independent, BBC and the Guardian as Reform, buoyed by poll rises, steps up legal pushback against critical coverage; the party insists it merely defends against untrue reporting.

articles.title: Nigel Farage responds to racism claims saying he never ‘tried to hurt anybody’
articles.trailText: Reform leader denies racist or antisemitic behaviour ‘with intent’ at school, but says he can’t remember everything from 49 years ago
articles.summary: After a Guardian investigation revealed some 20 former Dulwich College pupils accused Nigel Farage of racist and antisemitic schoolboy behaviour—singing a “Gas ’em all” song, targeting minority classmates and burning a roll with more Patels than Smiths—Farage, now Reform leader, denied any intent to hurt anyone, saying he can’t recall events from 49 years ago. His aides also refute the claims. Labour’s Keir Starmer labelled him “spineless” and peers and critics call for an apology and question his fitness for office.

articles.title: BBC finds its happy place inflicting latest round of self-harm | John Crace
articles.trailText: Chair Samir Shah is a picture of misery before MPs while Robbie Gibb proves the master of deflection
articles.summary: John Crace skewers the BBC’s compulsive self-examination after chair Samir Shah, board member Robbie Gibb and former standards adviser Michael Prescott testified before the Commons culture committee. Describing the session as the Beeb’s 'happiest place,' he depicts an organization obsessed with internal critique. Crace lampoons Prescott’s naïveté about his own 19-page memo—blamed for triggering the resignations of DG Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness—Shah’s grovelling apologies, and Gibb’s deft deflection of blame while touting his Tory impartiality. Highlighting the corporation’s solipsism and self-harm, Crace suggests the BBC may still have the wrong people in charge.

articles.title: Political corrrectness that made me laugh | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Corrections and clarifications | Weaponised real ale | More nominative determinism
articles.summary: Readers applaud the Guardian’s Corrections & Clarifications column for its wit, highlighting a 20 Nov correction that misattributed worst living standards to Labour and spurring a tongue-in-cheek bid for the title in the next four years. Sheffield’s Pete Bibby quips that real ale, not sci-fi ‘brain weapons,’ is the genuine mind-altering agent. Further letters play on nominative determinism with anecdotes about Mr Patient, Mr Killer, Mr Blewitt and the kindly Mr Swindells. Submissions are invited for future letters.

articles.title: Two peers suspended from House of Lords for breaking lobbying rules
articles.trailText: Lord Evans of Watford and Lord Dannatt were filmed breaking rules, in undercover footage recorded by Guardian
articles.summary: Crossbench peer Lord Richard Dannatt, ex‐British Army chief, was suspended four months after undercover Guardian footage showed him offering to secure ministerial meetings and lobbying on behalf of commercial clients—including a fertiliser project, US defence firm Teledyne and a Ghanaian goldmine—receiving multiple £2,000 payments. Labour peer Lord Evans of Watford, peer since 1998 and now stripped of the whip, was suspended five months for four breaches after offering to introduce undercover reporters as property developers to parliamentarians and promote his son’s paid parliamentary events. Both initially denied breaches but accepted sanctions from the Lords’ standards watchdog.

articles.title: Lords rules and culture make it easy for peers to abuse privileged position
articles.trailText: Unreformed system means peers can profit by taking outside roles based on insider knowledge and access
articles.summary: An official inquiry has suspended Lord Dannatt and Lord Evans after a Guardian sting revealed they offered to lobby ministers for property developers, breaching Lords’ code by using euphemisms like “facilitate conversations” to profit from privileged access. Both claim public-interest motives but violated “personal honour” standards. Critics say an unreformed Lords culture—growing membership, second-job allowances, minimal participation and no removal mechanism—encourages peers to monetize insider knowledge. Promised reforms remain stalled, leaving accountability gaps.

articles.title: Reform UK claim to have saved £331m at English councils – but do the numbers stack up?
articles.trailText: Experts say councils face limits on cuts as Reform’s savings on IT deals, office moves and EV projects are disputed
articles.summary: Reform UK’s claim to have delivered £331m in savings at 10 English councils since May is unsubstantiated and faces a £260m unexplained shortfall. Detailed review shows most cuts—scrapping EV fleet transitions (£7.5m), halting charging-point schemes (£4m), cancelling Maidstone HQ sale (£14m) and new IT contracts (£31.7m)—were pre-planned or based on short-term accounting. Proposed SEN and pension fee cuts lack legal basis or evidence. Experts warn councils have already exhausted easy savings, making further cuts risky for service delivery.

articles.title: Politicians urge Labour to restore Electoral Commission independence
articles.trailText: All-party group say move is needed to stop UK lagging behind global standards on election integrity
articles.summary: MPs and peers from across parties have written to Keir Starmer urging restoration of full independence to the UK Electoral Commission, arguing ministers’ current power to set its annual priorities—introduced under Boris Johnson—undermines election integrity and public trust. An elections bill next year will lower voting age to 16 and tighten donation rules, but resists reversing ministerial oversight. Campaigners including Lib Dem Lisa Smart, Green MP Ellie Chowns and Labour’s Phil Brickell warn political interference risks Reform UK and parallels with US abuses. New Unlock Democracy polling finds 70% support a politically free commission. Government insists operational independence remains intact.

articles.title: Farage urged to explain conspiracy theories linked to antisemitism he voiced in US media
articles.trailText: Exclusive: The Reform UK leader discussed far-right talking points in web TV and radio appearances between 2009 and 2018
articles.summary: Nigel Farage faces calls to explain why, between 2009 and 2018, he aired antisemitic conspiracy tropes—blaming Goldman Sachs, the Bilderberg group and George Soros for a global government—across six web TV interviews with Alex Jones and six web radio slots with Rick Wiles. After Jewish organisations in 2019 urged him to repudiate these “globalist” claims—which he never addressed—a cross-party chorus, citing fresh testimonies of his racist, antisemitic schoolboy remarks, now demands (Lib Dem Christine Jardine, Labour’s Anna Turley) he clarify his stance. Reform UK rejects the allegations.

articles.title: David Cameron reveals prostate cancer diagnosis and calls for targeted screening
articles.trailText: Former prime minister says he wants to join ranks of those pressing for more checks on men who may have disease
articles.summary: Former PM David Cameron, 59, disclosed a prostate cancer diagnosis after high PSA and biopsy and underwent focal therapy using electrical pulses. Prompted by his wife after hearing Nick Jones’s diagnosis, he urges a targeted screening programme as men often delay checks. Prostate cancer is the UK’s most common male cancer, with around 55,000 new cases yearly, yet no screening exists due to PSA accuracy concerns. His call aligns with the £16m Transform trial comparing blood tests and biopsies and upcoming UK screening committee decisions. Cameron, now a life peer and foreign secretary, says earlier detection boosts cure rates.

articles.title: Unions urge Reeves to prioritise living standards as CBI presses for shift on employment rights
articles.trailText: TUC calls on chancellor to focus on child poverty and upping minimum wage
articles.summary: TUC urged Chancellor Rachel Reeves to deliver a “living standards” budget, focusing on child poverty, a higher national living wage, scrapping the two-child benefit cap, freezing rail fares and cutting energy bills after real wages rose only £12/week since 2008 and public service pay flatlined. New polling shows 83% oppose child poverty. Meanwhile the CBI pressed for welfare and pension cuts and a rethink of the employment rights bill, warning higher NICs and worker-rights measures deter business growth.

articles.title: Boris Johnson took four days off as NHS warned Covid could ‘overwhelm’ system
articles.trailText: Files show then PM was walking dog, riding motorbike and hosting guests as pandemic planning stalled in ‘lost month’
articles.summary: Boris Johnson took four days off official duties (15–17, 21 Feb 2020) at Chevening, pursuing leisure—dog walks, motorbike rides, hosting guests—while the NHS warned Covid could overwhelm the system. The Covid inquiry labels February 2020 a “lost month,” noting no cabinet meetings, no PM briefings or Cobra attendance, contradicting Johnson’s sworn testimony of working throughout. Despite emerging Italian clusters and UK cases, he held only brief calls with Trump and Xi, delaying urgent planning and a mid-March lockdown, a response deemed “too little, too late,” costing over 20,000 lives and exposing a “toxic, chaotic” Downing Street culture.

articles.title: Twenty people allege he has a racist past. He denies it. Who’s telling the truth about Farage’s schooldays?
articles.trailText: Reform UK’s leader refuses to answer questions about his abusive behaviour, claiming there’s ‘no evidence’. We talk to victims and witnesses
articles.summary: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage denies allegations of racist and antisemitic abuse during his schooldays at Dulwich College, insisting through a spokesperson that there is ‘no primary evidence’ and accusing The Guardian of smearing him. But 20 contemporaries—including victims Peter Ettedgui and witnesses such as Anthony Butler, Jean-Pierre Lihou and former teacher Bob Jope—describe repeated slurs (‘Paki’, ‘wog’, ‘Jew’), chants of ‘Hitler was right’ and ‘gas ’em’, Nazi salutes, National Front slogans and racially motivated detentions. These testimonies, many on the record, fuel a growing row over who is telling the truth about Farage’s adolescent behaviour.

articles.title: ‘America is British’. Heaven is ‘a socialist state’. David Attenborough is ‘anti-human’ – the startling theories of Reform MP Danny Kruger
articles.trailText: He was a Conservative party big-hitter who wrote speeches for David Cameron and worked with Boris Johnson before he suddenly jumped ship. He talks family, flags and why Nigel Farage is ‘top dog’
articles.summary: Defected Tory MP Danny Kruger joined Reform UK citing Nigel Farage’s strong leadership and his own Burkean, evangelical vision of family, community and nation. Tasked with preparing the party for government, he’s formalized its structure and shifted focus from radical tax cuts to debt reduction. Kruger espouses provocative ideas: “America is British,” “heaven is socialist,” and labels David Attenborough “anti-human.” He champions flag‐waving as patriotic, denounces “woke” culture, advocates pro‐nuclear‐family fiscal incentives, defends stricter asylum rules and maintains moderate abortion limits. Educated at Eton and Oxford, and founder of Only Connect, Kruger wields intellectual flair to reshape post‐Brexit conservatism under Farage’s banner.

articles.title: Iqbal Mohamed becomes second MP to quit Your Party
articles.trailText: Mohamed says decision to leave was after ‘many false allegations and smears’ against him and others
articles.summary: Iqbal Mohamed, independent MP for Dewsbury and Batley, has become the second MP to resign from the leftwing Your Party this week, citing “false allegations and smears” against him and fellow members. His departure follows Adnan Hussain’s exit over “persistent infighting and power struggles.” Disputes between co-leaders Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana have intensified after delays in transferring £850,000 in donations via MOU Operations Ltd, plus a contested pre-conference rally. Mohamed will sit as an independent, wishing the party well despite its ongoing leadership and funding conflicts.

articles.title: Nigel Farage urged to root out Reform links to Russia after jailing of Nathan Gill
articles.trailText: Party’s former leader in Wales admitted taking payments to make statements in favour of Russia
articles.summary: After a week of damaging revelations, former Reform UK Wales leader Nathan Gill was sentenced to 10 years for accepting at least £30,000 in Kremlin-backed bribes from alleged Russian agent Oleg Voloshyn to make pro-Putin statements in the European Parliament and on 112 Ukraine. Police uncovered WhatsApp messages showing Gill enlisted other ex-Ukip and Brexit Party MEPs to echo Kremlin narratives unwittingly. Keir Starmer urged Nigel Farage to launch a full inquiry into party donors, structures and membership for pro-Russian ties. Farage dismissed Gill as a ‘bad apple’ and deflected onto Labour’s China links.

articles.title: Starmer rebuffs renewed talk of Andy Burnham leadership challenge
articles.trailText: Starmer rebuffs renewed talk of Andy Burnham leadership challenge
articles.summary: Keir Starmer attempts to quell speculation over a leadership challenge from Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham, praising his performance and urging Labour MPs to avoid internal briefings as the party struggles in polls ahead of a tax‐raising budget. Burnham declined to rule out future ambitions while promoting a £1bn growth plan, reigniting talks of a potential bid. Starmer, en route to the G20 in Johannesburg where he’ll secure trade deals and rally support for Ukraine, emphasised focusing on the cost of living and respecting journalists after Trump’s derisory remark.

articles.title: Farage’s views on Russia likely to be further tested after jailing of Nathan Gill
articles.trailText: It would be expedient for Reform to take Labour’s advice and disavow ‘Putin talking points’
articles.summary: Reform UK’s credibility is under scrutiny after former MEP Nathan Gill was jailed for taking payments from Moscow to spread pro-Russian propaganda, highlighting entrenched sympathy for Putin within Nigel Farage’s circles. Gill’s case—alongside colleagues who echoed Kremlin talking points without reward—reshapes concerns over Farage’s past 17 appearances on RT and his praise for Putin as a shrewd operator.
