Reform, sensing electoral risk amid public pro-Ukraine sentiment, has denounced Gill’s “treasonous” actions, but Labour is urging Farage to root out lingering pro-Russia views and repudiate claims that the West provoked the Ukraine war.

articles.title: Starmer accuses ‘spineless’ Farage of failure to tackle racism in Reform party
articles.trailText: PM says Reform UK leader also has ‘questions to answer’ about alleged racist comments and chants at school
articles.summary: Keir Starmer has branded Reform UK leader Nigel Farage “spineless” for ignoring allegations of racist and antisemitic chants and bullying of minority pupils at Dulwich College in his teens, and for failing to discipline MP Sarah Pochin after her “ugly” comments about adverts featuring black and Asian people. Dozens of former classmates recount Holocaust songs, Nazi salutes and targeting of ethnic children. Farage denies all claims as “one person’s word” and says voters will judge both him and Starmer at next May’s election.

articles.title: Reform UK’s former Wales leader jailed for taking bribes for pro-Russia speeches
articles.trailText: Police say Nathan Gill received at least £30,000 while he was an MEP, from Oleg Voloshyn, an alleged Russian asset
articles.summary: Ex-Reform UK Wales leader Nathan Gill has been sentenced to 10½ years by the Old Bailey for eight counts of bribery, admitting he took at least £30,000 from Oleg Voloshyn, an alleged Russian asset, between December 2018 and July 2019. Gill used his MEP platform to deliver pro-Kremlin narratives on Ukraine in the European Parliament and via Ukraine’s 112 TV and arranged statements from other MEPs. Justice Cheema-Grubb condemned the betrayal; police continue investigating Voloshyn’s high-treason charges in Ukraine. Defence minister Al Carns and Lib Dem Ed Davey urge probes into Reform UK’s Russian links.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves sick of people ‘mansplaining’ how to be chancellor
articles.trailText: As she prepares to deliver her budget next week, Reeves speaks of pressure of being UK’s first female chancellor
articles.summary: Rachel Reeves, the UK's first female chancellor, expressed frustration with male pundits ‘mansplaining’ her role ahead of her upcoming budget, where she’ll propose £20bn+ in tax rises—lowering income thresholds, gambling and high-value property levies, pensions relief tweaks—and cost-of-living measures including a frozen NHS prescription charge. Under constant media attack, she vows clearer communication, cutting NHS waiting lists by 230,000, curbing national debt and funding public services despite unpopularity, high borrowing and debates over tax cuts versus spending.

articles.title: Lib Dems to force vote on creating new customs union with EU
articles.trailText: Ed Davey’s party believes the move is the best way to ‘turbocharge’ economy, rather than tax rises
articles.summary: The Liberal Democrats, led by Ed Davey, will force an early December vote on Al Pinkerton’s bill to establish a bespoke UK–EU customs union covering most goods (excluding agriculture) by 2030. Although largely symbolic and lacking government support, it aims to pressure Labour MPs—citing NBER’s 6–8% Brexit-induced GDP loss and a Commons Library estimate of £25bn annual revenue gains—to back closer EU ties. The plan would cut red tape, consult the UK on EU trade deals and supplement existing agreements. Starmer’s government maintains a customs union red line.

articles.title: Labour MPs urge Reeves to drop private finance plans for NHS buildings
articles.trailText: Chancellor told PFI-style schemes familiar from New Labour era are ‘fiscal illusion’ offering no value for money
articles.summary: Forty Labour MPs, including Cat Eccles, Clive Lewis and Rebecca Long-Bailey, have written to Chancellor Rachel Reeves urging her to abandon plans for private finance initiatives (PFIs) to build NHS facilities. They argue PFIs, familiar from the New Labour era, impose costly debt—80 trusts still repaying a combined £44bn—and offer no value for money, a ‘fiscal illusion’ per the OBR and NAO. While the government’s 10-year health and infrastructure plans envisage limited new public–private partnerships for primary centres and decarbonisation projects, MPs and over 50 academics warn such schemes risk repeating PFI’s failures.

articles.title: Cryptocurrency backed by Farage donor is used for Russian war effort, investigators say
articles.trailText: Tether tokens found to facilitate scheme that enables sanctions evasion and launders money for the Kremlin
articles.summary: British NCA investigators say a stablecoin backed by Christopher Harborne, a major donor to Nigel Farage, has been exploited to launder proceeds from UK drug and gun sales, evade sanctions and finance Russia’s military-industrial base in Ukraine’s war. Operation Destabilise uncovered $24m seized, predominantly Tether USDT, and linked two laundering networks—Smart and TGR—to arms-component exports and a Kremlin spy ring. Harborne’s 12% Tether stake funded £10m to the Brexit Party and other political gifts, though he denies wrongdoing. The NCA warns crypto firms must curb illicit flows.

articles.title: Keir Starmer defends trip to South Africa for G20 summit as budget looms
articles.trailText: PM says he aims to secure investment to help deal with cost of living and shore up support for Ukraine
articles.summary: Labour prime minister Keir Starmer defends his pre-budget trip to South Africa for the G20 summit, arguing securing foreign investment is vital to boost UK jobs and tackle the cost-of-living crisis. Arriving Friday, he’ll discuss sustainability, economic growth and pursue support for Ukraine amid Donald Trump’s boycott, Russia’s Putin and China’s Xi’s absences. Starmer will hold bilateral talks with leaders including Germany’s Merz, France’s Macron, Italy’s Meloni and Turkey’s Erdoğan. Meanwhile Chancellor Reeves finalises a budget expected to raise £20bn through tax freezes, stressing fairness after years of austerity and crises.

articles.title: Ministers call on Nigel Farage to address ‘repulsive’ teenage racism allegations
articles.trailText: Liz Kendall and Jo Stevens intervene after about 20 people claim they witnessed or were victims of Farage’s behaviour
articles.summary: Cabinet ministers Liz Kendall and Jo Stevens have branded new reports of Nigel Farage’s alleged teenage racist abuse as “repulsive” and backed calls from Keir Starmer for Farage to respond. About 20 former Dulwich College students, including director Peter Ettedgui, recount slurs like “Hitler was right” and “gas them” in the late 1970s. Farage’s team dismisses the allegations as one person’s word against another. Critics fault his blanket denial and question if past views inform his current policies.

articles.title: Familiarity breeds contempt as Shabana does her double act | John Crace
articles.trailText: Even Reform MPs failed to show up to hear the home secretary talk about migration, their specialist subject
articles.summary: John Crace satirizes Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood’s twin Commons statements on illegal and legal immigration: after praising her first dog-whistle crackdown for drawing Reform applause, she told the BBC Political Thinking podcast she’d offer £10,000 per asylum-seeker to self-deport—up from £3,000 to avoid £30,000 court costs—creating a perverse ferry-back-and-forth business. Her legal migration package then raised ILR thresholds to ten years’ residency, A-level English, spotless criminal and debt records plus paid NI. MPs across Reform, the Tories and Labour largely skipped her follow-up, reflecting fatigue. Mahmood admits her party embraced nastier tactics to woo a narrowing patriotism while lamenting No 10’s bungled leaks around her and Wes Streeting.

articles.title: UK government insists it is ‘taking time to get this right’ on single-sex spaces
articles.trailText: Labour accused of delaying new rules to avoid backlash, after leak of EHRC guidance saying trans people could be questioned based on looks
articles.summary: The UK government is holding up formal EHRC guidance on implementing April’s Supreme Court ruling on biological sex to ensure provisions for women’s single-sex spaces are robust, Equalities Minister Bridget Phillipson says. Labour critics accuse ministers of deliberate delay after a Times leak revealed proposed measures allowing providers (hospitals, gyms, rape crisis centres) to question trans people’s facility use based on appearance or stereotypes. Children’s Minister Josh MacAlister warns that rushing risks fresh legal challenges, businesses label the rules unworkable, a judicial review looms, and trans activists condemn the draft as exclusionary.

articles.title: Joy Crookes says UK and Ireland in ‘dark time’ amid rise of far-right politics
articles.trailText: Musician’s Brixton and Dublin performances go viral after she performs Sinéad O’Connor’s anti-racism anthem Black Boys on Mopeds
articles.summary: British-Bangladeshi-Irish singer Joy Crookes warns the UK and Ireland are entering a “dark time” as far-right nationalism resurges to levels she compares with the 1970s National Front. After sold-out shows in Brixton and Dublin, she said seeing St George’s flags in London and Irish tricolours in Dublin made her, as a child of immigrants, feel unsafe. A viral clip of her cover of Sinéad O’Connor’s anti-racism anthem “Black Boys on Mopeds” amplifies her plea for solidarity against racism and urges fellow artists to speak out.

articles.title: Reform’s Welsh hopes damaged after Senedd member suspended for ‘vile’ racial slur
articles.trailText: Parliament suspends Laura Anne Jones, Reform’s only Senedd member, for two weeks in further blow after party lost Caerphilly byelection
articles.summary: Reform UK’s only Senedd member, Laura Anne Jones, has been suspended without pay for two weeks after using a racist Chinese slur in a private office WhatsApp group, following an inquiry by standards commissioner Douglas Bain. The Senedd’s conduct committee approved the penalty, marking a setback for Reform’s ambitions in next year’s Welsh elections after its Caerphilly by-election loss. Jones, who defected from the Conservatives this summer, has apologized for her language and cited severe personal distress amid the controversy.

articles.title: No 10 calls on Farage to urgently address ‘disturbing allegations’ of past racist behaviour
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer ramps up pressure on Reform leader, who has dismissed claims as ‘one person’s word against another’
articles.summary: At PMQs, Keir Starmer demanded Nigel Farage explain ‘disturbing’ allegations of racist and antisemitic bullying at Dulwich College, as reported by the Guardian. More than a dozen school contemporaries, including director Peter Ettedgui, recount slurs, gas-em-all chants and targeting of minority classmates. Farage denies the claims as unsubstantiated, blaming faulty decades-old memories. Former extremism adviser Lord Walney warns his blanket denial is “troubling.” Labour, Lib Dems and campaigners urge him to address these detailed testimonies or face questions over Reform UK’s stance on racism.

articles.title: China’s power play: MI5 warns of relentless espionage attempts in Britain
articles.trailText: Alert says Beijing trying to recruit British sources in parliament, even if potential gains may be unclear
articles.summary: MI5 warns of relentless Chinese espionage attempts in Britain, highlighting a surge of LinkedIn approaches by the Ministry of State Security using recruiters offering cash or crypto for geopolitical reports. Since 2021, around 10,000 Britons—MPs, peers, staff, academics and industry experts—have been targeted. A leaked alert via parliament’s speakers urges vigilance under the new National Security Act, which criminalises any assistance to foreign agencies. The campaign reflects Beijing’s broad intelligence push, from human recruitment to cyber operations like Salt and Volt Typhoon, as part of its geopolitical contest with the West.

articles.title: A guttural groan in an energy-free zone: sullen resignation haunts PMQs
articles.trailText: Usually raucous backbenchers snoozed through the session as Keir and Kemi’s exchanges descended into a slanging match
articles.summary: John Crace lampoons a moribund PMQs where Labour’s Keir Starmer and Tory leader Kemi Badenoch traded personal insults over budget chaos, stealth taxes and frozen income thresholds. Whips’ pressure yields sullen backbenchers who grunt instead of ‘lively’ questions. With May’s local elections looming, internal Tory dissent and Labour despair spark leadership rumors—from Clive Lewis’s seat-offer to Andy Burnham, to speculation over Starmer’s tenure. Reform’s Lee Anderson bizarrely attacked Labour’s immigration plan amid council tax hikes, while Farage dodged past racism allegations. The result: a dysfunctional, energy-free Commons spectacle.

articles.title: ‘He used to say things like ‘Hitler was right’’: Farage faces more allegations of racist behaviour at school
articles.trailText: A former friend and others who were at Dulwich college with the now Reform UK leader speak of his behaviour
articles.summary: At Dulwich College classmates of Nigel Farage, including Jean-Pierre Lihou and director Peter Ettedgui, allege the future Reform UK leader engaged in racist and fascist mockery as a teenager: chanting ‘Gas em all’ alongside slurs against Jews, Pakistanis and Black people; praising Hitler and Oswald Mosley; saluting Nazi imagery in playground shows. More than a dozen contemporaries corroborate patterned bigotry. Farage denies all claims as ‘smears’. Lihou says these teenage behaviors presage Farage’s current rhetoric, warning his charisma masks normalized racism. Others recall Farage growling ‘Hitler was right,’ hissing slurs at Jewish peers, and polishing boots as pseudo-fascist roleplay.

articles.title: Ask young Reform voters their views | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Canvassing opinion | From A Lane to the bus lane | GWR wifi | Suits in the White House | Blancmange rabbit | Narcissism
articles.summary: Brief letters in The Guardian: Nigel Scollin urges polling young Reform UK supporters in red-wall towns like Mansfield and Derby rather than Gen Z activists; Nicholas Gough recalls his driving examiner Mr A Lane in Wales; Leigh Hughes criticises GWR’s focus on onboard wifi over train efficiency; Philip Robins queries Mohammed bin Salman’s casual attire during his White House visit; Catriona Graham shares blancmange rabbit decoration tips; Pete Bibby wonders why a narcissism article ignored him; finally, readers are invited to submit their own letters for possible publication. Topics span politics, transport, culture and cooking tips.

articles.title: Reform UK councillor suspended over WhatsApp group featuring extremist posts
articles.trailText: Tom Pickup confirms he was member of group in which one participant allegedly called for ‘mass Islam genocide’
articles.summary: Reform UK county councillor Tom Pickup was suspended after admitting membership of a rightwing WhatsApp group where members allegedly called for “mass Islam genocide”, urged stockpiling weapons and attacked politicians. Pickup, Lancashire’s lead member for finance, said his own posts—mocking Keir Starmer as a “dicktaker” and endorsing mass deportations—were “jokey” and taken out of context. He denied awareness of the extremist calls and claimed he’d deleted messages after 24 hours. Labour figures have demanded his resignation and reported him to watchdogs, while Reform UK investigates and Pickup now sits as an independent councillor.

articles.title: ‘I thought the grownups were back in charge!’: John Crace on how Labour shattered his expectations
articles.trailText: After 14 years of Tory rule, the Guardian’s parliamentary sketch writer thought he had seen it all. Westminster would surely tick along nicely once Keir Starmer’s party took over. How wrong he was ...
articles.summary: After praising the return of ‘grownup’ politics under Keir Starmer, John Crace finds Westminster still a circus: Rishi Sunak’s doomed premiership hit only one of five pledges amid spectacle-made-for-TV blunders; Labour’s squeaky-clean brand marred by freebies and suit-and-glasses rows, Angela Rayner’s stamp-duty mishap and policy U-turns on winter fuel allowances, inheritance tax and welfare cuts. He profiles a feisty Tory opposition under Kemi Badenoch, Nigel Farage’s surging Reform party, Trump’s BBC lawsuit and Starmer’s cautious diplomacy—proving politics remains prime satire fodder.

articles.title: ‘Out of touch’ hereditary peers criticised for voting against workers’ rights
articles.trailText: Lords look ‘undemocratic and firmly against interest of working people’, say senior trade union and Labour figures
articles.summary: Hereditary peers – 47 (including the 9th Duke of Wellington), 93 barons, 16 earls and seven viscounts – backed Conservative amendments to Labour’s employment rights bill for a third time, seeking to delay guaranteed hours contracts and day-one unfair dismissal protections. TUC’s Paul Nowak, Unison’s Christina McAnea and MP Justin Madders decry unelected Lords as archaic and undemocratic. Business figures like Karren Brady and Karan Bilimoria warn the changes could cost jobs and push up prices ahead of the autumn budget, but ministers insist they will overturn peers’ votes to deliver manifesto-promised rights to 15 million workers.

articles.title: Only Labour could turn victory into defeat | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers weigh in on the backfired briefings from Keir Starmer’s team against supposed leadership challengers
articles.summary: Two readers—from Rugby, Warwickshire, and Stoke-on-Trent—criticize Labour's internal 'briefing war' spotlighting tensions among senior figures and an attempt to smear potential challenger Wes Streeting, which they say distracts from governance. They argue Keir Starmer's leadership still lacks a clear, persuasive purpose beyond distancing from Corbynism and the Conservatives and offers no new solutions to national crises. They highlight the absence of new ideas to tackle multiple national challenges. They urge ministers to act in the country's interest to restore public confidence, rather than resorting to triangulation and anonymous briefings.

articles.title: Tories and Reform spout imaginary numbers as they fight for attention | John Crace
articles.trailText: Back-of-an envelope calculations by Kemi Badenoch, Mel Stride and Nigel Farage are nothing but political fever dreams
articles.summary: John Crace skewers a surreal press day in Westminster where, three and a half years before an election, Tory figures Kemi Badenoch and Mel Stride used ‘back-of-an-envelope’ claims to vow £47bn in welfare cuts via two-child caps and unspecified secret savings. Stride merely echoed her lines despite presiding over benefit growth as Work and Pensions Secretary. Nearby Reform’s Nigel Farage proposed ending most foreign aid, hiking NHS charges for migrants and halting universal credit for non-nationals — all bluster met with scepticism as Labour’s Starmer scolded internal leaks.

articles.title: Starmer pleads for government to unite in fightback after difficult week
articles.trailText: Prime minister tells cabinet budget leaks and infighting are distracting from priorities and delivering change
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer urged his cabinet to end infighting and leaks after a turbulent week dominated by rumours of a leadership challenge from Health Secretary Wes Streeting and a leaked pre-budget U-turn ditching planned income tax rises in favour of smaller levies. He warned distractions were diverting from voters’ priorities and demanded unity to deliver on rebuilding the economy and cost-of-living measures. Streeting publicly backed Starmer, dispelling coup talk. Starmer confirmed he will lead Labour into the next election, stressed delivering results over politics, and refocused his team ahead of next week’s budget.

articles.title: Most Reform UK voters would back wealth tax on very rich, poll suggests
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Best for Britain thinktank says the figures show Nigel Farage is ‘out of step with his base’ on taxation
articles.summary: A YouGov poll of 3,000 prospective Reform UK voters for Best for Britain finds 61% support a one-off wealth tax on households worth over £10m, 77% back a windfall tax on energy firms and 73% on high bank profits. While Nigel Farage opposes wealth taxes except on renewables, most supporters have negative views of energy (59%) and banks (40%). Support for these levies is even higher among Labour (82%), Lib Dem (81%), Green (85%) and Conservative (63%) voters. Campaigners say the findings give Chancellor Rachel Reeves a mandate to pursue fairer taxation.

articles.title: Reform would ‘cut benefits for EU nationals and hike NHS immigration surcharge’
articles.trailText: Party claims its policies would eliminate ‘black hole’ Rachel Reeves faces in the budget – but Labour says the ‘fantasy numbers don’t add up’
articles.summary: Reform UK, led by Nigel Farage, would bar EU, EEA and Swiss nationals—including those with settled status—from claiming universal credit after a three-month notice (saving £6bn/year), tear up parts of the post-Brexit deal risking EU retaliation, cap overseas aid at £1bn (a 90% cut), triple the NHS surcharge to £2,718 (raising £5bn) and deport foreign criminals (recouping £580m). The party touts £25bn in annual savings to fill Rachel Reeves’ budget gap; Labour dismisses the figures as fantasy, warning of higher costs and trade reprisals.

articles.title: Shabana Mahmood puts the signs up: Britain is full. No blacks, no dogs, no Irish
articles.trailText: We had always given sanctuary to those who needed it, she said, only now we would kick them out as soon as possible
articles.summary: John Crace’s scathing satirical column portrays a dystopian scene in which Labour home secretary Shabana Mahmood enacts draconian, retrospective deportation measures—even booting herself out—under slogans like “Britain is full. No blacks, no dogs, no Irish.” In Downing Street, Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves cheer on mass deportations and asset confiscation, setting up a ‘department of looting.’ Conservative ministers outdo each other demanding ever more brutal expulsion, prompting queasy Labour backbenchers to question their party’s abandonment of compassion. Crace skewers the rightward shift and inhumanity of modern immigration policy.

articles.title: Letter: Lord Taverne obituary
articles.trailText: Marcelo Staricoff writes: Dick Taverne handed over his parliamentary science communicator award of £500 for the benefit of the children
articles.summary: Marcelo Staricoff recalls that after his family fled Argentina in 1976, Janice and Dick Taverne supported them when their bank accounts were frozen during the 1982 Falklands conflict and later helped secure their British citizenship. In 2007, Dick Taverne donated his £500 parliamentary science communicator award to benefit pupils at St Bartholomew’s CE primary school in Brighton, where Staricoff was deputy headteacher, ensuring the funds were put to good use for the children.

articles.title: UK downplays reports it has stopped sharing intelligence with US regarding narco-traffickers
articles.trailText: Yvette Cooper makes first public comments by minister over issue linked to bombing campaign in Caribbean
articles.summary: On a ministerial visit to Naples, foreign secretary Yvette Cooper rejected reports that the UK had halted intelligence sharing with the US on Caribbean narco-traffickers, affirming continued cooperation under longstanding frameworks. US officials, including Secretary of State and Senator Marco Rubio, dismissed CNN’s claims as false. The dispute follows a US bombing campaign from USS Gerald R. Ford against suspected traffickers linked to Venezuela, raising legal questions over non-international conflict and civilian targeting. UK warships remain on IHL-compliant duties.

articles.title: How to stop the rise of Reform UK? Expose its contradictions | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: The victory of Nigel Farage’s party at the next election need not be inevitable, writes Les Bright . Plus letters from Nick Moss , and Dr Margherita de Candia and Marianna Griffini
articles.summary: Letters from Les Bright, Nick Moss, Margherita de Candia and Marianna Griffini argue that Nigel Farage’s Reform UK victory isn’t inevitable. Data on supporters and polling expose a fragile coalition that can be weakened by highlighting contradictions in its policy mix—‘microwaved Thatcherism’ with private-school tax relief, harsh benefits cuts, training camps for offenders and anti-immigration scapegoating. Unlike Giorgia Meloni’s Italy, the UK’s first-past-the-post system and absence of EU checks mean Reform could impose unrestrained attacks on the working class and migrants if left unchallenged.

articles.title: Wasted public money and Rachel Reeves’s income tax hokey cokey | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Michael Bichard , John Denham , Liam Byrne and Helen Bailey on making better use of current resources, Dan Goss on making the case for tax rises, and Jol Miskin on a U-turn
articles.summary: In letters discussing the chancellor’s spending and tax agenda, ex-officials Michael Bichard, John Denham, Liam Byrne and Helen Bailey argue for reviving Total Place pilots and place-based budgets to break service silos, shift funding toward prevention and deliver better outcomes without extra funds. Demos researcher Dan Goss urges the chancellor to articulate a positive case for income tax rises paired with wealth levies and fairer partnership taxes to rebuild public support. And Jol Miskin quips that Rachel Reeves’s income tax U-turn merits a ‘Strictly’ hokey cokey.

articles.title: No 10 turns to influencers to reach audiences beyond mainstream media
articles.trailText: Critics view increasing use of digital content creators to push policy as way to avoid serious scrutiny of decisions
articles.summary: Downing Street is enlisting TikTok and Instagram influencers to broadcast policy messages for Keir Starmer’s Labour government, aiming to engage the half of Britons who get news on social media. Science communicator Simon Clark, “mumfluencer” Mother Pukka and personal finance creators Cameron Smith and Abi Foster have all been hosted at Cop30, childcare roundtables and Rachel Reeves’s press conference. Led by Caitlin Roper’s New Media Unit, events like a No 10 “creators’ breakfast” and summer reception drew 80 influencers with quarter-billion followers. Critics warn this sidelines rigorous journalism, risks political pushback and blurs the line between marketing and scrutiny.

articles.title: Angela Rayner declines to rule out running for Labour leader as she condemns infighting
articles.trailText: Former deputy PM hits out at ‘arrogant tittle-tattle’ over the past week and says she has ‘not gone away’
articles.summary: Allies of former deputy PM Angela Rayner say she plans to revive her profile and might contest the Labour leadership in future after condemning recent ‘arrogant tittle-tattle’ and infighting. In her first major interview she refused to rule out a bid, insisting she “has not gone away,” but stressed any decision would hinge on safeguarding her family following her stamp duty resignation. Now aligned with the Tribune soft-left group, she criticised plotting against Wes Streeting and urged colleagues to end mortifying speculation and focus on government work.

articles.title: When reality bites: the rapid rise and chaotic fall of Reform UK in Cornwall
articles.trailText: Resignations, suspensions and infighting lead to party losing crown of highest number of seats in the county
articles.summary: Reform UK’s breakthrough in May’s Cornwall council elections saw it win 28 seats, the largest share, but six months on it’s teetering: resignations, suspensions and infighting have slashed its tally to 23 seats, behind the Liberal Democrats’ 26 in the ruling coalition. Former deputy Rowland O’Connor and leader Rob Parsonage resigned—forming an Independent Non-aligned group—citing national HQ interference on net zero and immigration policy. Christine Parsonage, suspended branch chairs and criticism of paper candidates reveal friction between Reform’s national agenda and local service priorities, although new leader Paul Ashton denies any top-down directives.

articles.title: Wes Streeting accused of ‘chaotic and incoherent approach’ to NHS reform
articles.trailText: Exclusive: thinktank report finds health secretary has failed to improve productivity and the health service is unlikely to meet its targets
articles.summary: An Institute for Government report accuses Health Secretary Wes Streeting of a chaotic, incoherent approach to NHS reform—lambasting his rushed abolition of NHS England, ignored GP partner exodus, cuts in integrated care boards and contradictory community-care plans—and warns the government will struggle to meet 18-week referral, A&E, cancer and adult social care targets. It nonetheless praises improved hospital performance, record GP growth, lowest non-pandemic staff turnover and averted winter strikes. The DHSC defends reintegrating NHS England to free £1bn for frontline, deliver record appointments, productivity gains, £1.1bn primary-care investment and new neighbourhood contracts. Streeting, tipped as a potential PM successor, faces intense scrutiny ahead of this month’s budget.

articles.title: Nigel Farage is today’s Enoch Powell and his appeal down to slow economy, says minister
articles.trailText: Business secretary Peter Kyle says appeal of far-right parties like Reform due to ‘their dogma of disruption, division and despair’
articles.summary: At the Co-operative party conference, Business Secretary Peter Kyle likened Nigel Farage to Enoch Powell, accusing the far-right Reform UK of peddling “disruption, division and despair” by exploiting sluggish economic growth. He warned only sustained growth can rebuild trust in democracy and good government. Kyle pointed to Reform’s new student wing leader’s remarks questioning the British identity of UK-born minorities and recalled branding Farage’s opposition to the Online Safety Act as siding with abusers.

articles.title: ‘They all think Keir is done’: how push to protect Starmer’s job backfired spectacularly
articles.trailText: Botched briefing operation was proof to many that PM is leading an ineffectual No 10. How did it go so wrong?
articles.summary: Allies of PM Keir Starmer’s attempted leak to smother speculation of a coup—accusing Wes Streeting of scheming to oust him—has only underscored No 10’s fragility. MPs across factions, citing backtracked budget income-tax hikes as evidence of panic, now openly discuss coordinated action to replace Starmer. Front-runners include Streeting and Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood, each with surreptitious campaigns, while Andy Burnham, Angela Rayner, Ed Miliband and others linger as dark-horse contenders. YouGov shows Streeting favoured by members but trailing Rayner, and Burnham with the strongest combined public and party ratings. With the budget looming, the leadership drama is set to intensify.

articles.title: MP Adnan Hussain quits Your Party over ‘persistent infighting’
articles.trailText: Blackburn MP criticises ‘struggle for power’ amid tensions between Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana
articles.summary: Blackburn MP Adnan Hussain resigned from the leftwing Your Party, citing “persistent infighting, factional competition and power struggles” among its leadership, particularly between co-chairs Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana. Hussain, secretary of the party’s limited company, criticised delays in transferring £850,000 in membership levies and alleged “veiled prejudice” against Muslim MPs. He had joined Corbyn’s camp to demand the funds, timed before Sultana’s BBC Question Time appearance, provoking accusations of undermining her leadership bid. Sultana’s allies argue legal barriers prevent immediate transfer, while critics insist the party urgently needs the money to finance an upcoming conference and pay volunteer staff.

articles.title: Trump’s targeting of alleged drug vessels strains UK-US intelligence ties
articles.trailText: Suspension of intelligence cooperation in Caribbean is unusual move and there is potential for political fallout
articles.summary: Britain has quietly halted intelligence sharing with the US in the Caribbean, its first public rupture in the decades-old UKUSA alliance, over legal objections to Trump’s lethal campaign against vessels he labels narco-terrorists. Since September, US forces sank ships in 19 strikes, killing 75 people, citing a “non-international armed conflict,” but experts argue such force breaches international law absent imminent threat. Officials say London feared legal complicity and autonomy in surveillance, recalling past Obama-era drone disputes. The pause, leaked to CNN, risks political fallout as the UK balances scrutiny of Trump’s hard-line tactics with sustaining the special relationship.

articles.title: Britons living abroad: tell us your views on UK politics today
articles.trailText: We want to hear from Brits living overseas on their views on UK politics today
articles.summary: This call-out invites British expatriates to share how the UK’s political upheavals – six prime ministers in ten years, national division up from 74% in 2020 to 84%, and a splintered polling landscape with Reform at 31%, Labour 18%, Conservatives 16%, Greens 14% and Lib Dems 12% – have shaped their perspectives. Respondents are asked how UK politics has changed since they left, what surprises them, how living abroad influences their views and any concerns they have.

articles.title: Your Party receives ‘small portion’ of withheld supporters’ donations
articles.trailText: Row continues between camps of Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana, whose company holds hundreds of thousands of pounds of party funds
articles.summary: Your Party, founded by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana, remains locked in a finance dispute: supporters donated hundreds of thousands to MOU Operations Ltd, but only a “small portion” was released to the party. Corbyn and allied MPs lament restricted funds hampering volunteers’ conference preparations, and demand transfer of the remaining sum close to £800k. Sultana, as sole director of MOU, offered £600k but held back funds for legal expenses, scheduling an initial £200k transfer on Nov 12 with balances contingent on liability settlements. Party officials threaten legal action to secure all donations and resolve governance issues.

articles.title: Starmer defies calls to sack chief of staff, claiming briefing didn’t come from No 10
articles.trailText: PM stands by Morgan McSweeney and attempts to draw line under row in which leaks suggested Wes Streeting would launch a leadership challenge
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer has defended his chief of staff Morgan McSweeney and denied that briefings casting Cabinet ministers as plotting against him originated from No 10. After leaks suggesting Health Secretary Wes Streeting might mount a leadership challenge, Starmer apologized to Streeting, warned his team against internal leaks and said he had assurance No Downing Street staff were involved. While some Labour MPs demanded McSweeney’s resignation and ministers hinted at a leak inquiry, Starmer opted not to launch a formal investigation, stressing high standards for staff and vowing to discipline anyone responsible for undermining colleagues.

articles.title: Labour must accept that the two-party age is over and embrace PR | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Backing proportional representation would be in Labour’s interests, writes John Culley , while Austen Lynch says the greater risk is continuing with the current system
articles.summary: Letters to The Guardian argue Labour should embrace proportional representation (PR) as Britain’s two-party system fragments. John Culley warns that 2024 election results and Electoral Calculus forecasts could cost Labour up to 90% of its seats under first-past-the-post, making PR a pragmatic hedge. Austen Lynch notes the 2024 outcome left 57.8% of voters unrepresented and risks small parties forming a government without broad support. Both writers urge Labour’s leadership to overcome political inertia and adopt PR for fairer, more representative election results.

articles.title: Keir clubs himself with the lead pipe in a Downing Street game of No Cluedo | John Crace
articles.trailText: The prime minister’s short-term memory is shot to pieces. Just who could be behind these dastardly briefings?
articles.summary: John Crace lampoons Keir Starmer’s Downing Street meltdown, portraying him playing a fatal game of Cluedo on himself as briefings leak against Wes Streeting, Shabana Mahmood and Ed Miliband. Starmer’s memory allegedly fails him, forcing self-investigations and yielding confused apologies. Chief of staff Morgan McSweeney is blamed for ‘red-on-red’ leaks, prompting a sham inquiry that will uncover only pre-approved truths. Streeting and Miliband dismiss the drama as media invention, while Starmer vows severe penalties for leakers and thanks divine intervention for proving his premiership. The farcical saga underlines Labour’s internal chaos and spin dysfunction.

articles.title: Why some in No 10 think Wes Streeting is plotting to become prime minister
articles.trailText: Health secretary has always been open about his ambitions but recent actions hinted at reasons for potential coup plot
articles.summary: Westminster’s fascination with Health Secretary Wes Streeting has peaked after a resurfaced 2018 clip showed him predicting he’d be prime minister and sparked No 10’s preemptive briefings on his ambitions. A former NUS leader and Blairite critic of Corbyn, Streeting championed private NHS partnerships, welfare reform and banned puberty blockers for minors. Recently he’s tacked left—backing Palestinian statehood, tougher Israel sanctions, anti-racism, digital-ID and welfare critiques, and rebuked Starmer’s immigration and fuel-cut proposals—outflanking the PM, leveraging a more moderate membership base and intensifying coup speculations despite rivals Burnham’s seat gap and Rayner’s resignation.

articles.title: London congestion charge to rise to £18 – and electric vehicles will have to pay
articles.trailText: Motoring groups criticise changes for making it ‘harder to go green’ though discounts of up to 50% will apply
articles.summary: From January London’s congestion charge will jump 20% from £15 to £18 and, for the first time, apply to electric vehicles: EV cars pay £13.50 (25% discount) and electric vans/HGVs £9 (50%). Mayor Sadiq Khan argues the change will prevent up to 2,200 extra vehicles entering the zone daily and keep traffic levels down. Existing 90% resident discounts will apply only to EVs from March 2027, while EV car clubs remain exempt. Motoring groups and Labour warn it could deter drivers from going green. Meanwhile, ministers are exploring a UK-wide EV pay-per-mile levy.

articles.title: If No 10 briefer is found Keir Starmer will sack them, Miliband says
articles.trailText: Cabinet minister says PM would not have backed attacks on Wes Streeting but briefing is ‘longstanding aspect of politics’
articles.summary: Ed Miliband says Keir Starmer will sack whoever briefed against Health Secretary Wes Streeting after a chaotic 48-hour No 10 operation to shore up the PM amid leadership rumblings. Starmer apologised to Streeting, insisted no Downing Street staff were involved and warned that “briefings against cabinet ministers are completely unacceptable” with “consequences” for offenders. Pressure builds on chief of staff Morgan McSweeney, while Labour chair Anna Turley has launched an inquiry. Miliband decries the longstanding culture of political briefings but is confident Starmer will act once the source is found.

articles.title: Labour faces questions over Starmer aide who holds shares in lobbying firm
articles.trailText: Communications chief Tim Allan left Strand Partners in September but still holds a minority stake
articles.summary: Labour communications chief Tim Allan retains a minority stake in lobbying firm Strand Partners despite stepping down as its chair when joining No 10 in September. Although he receives no dividends and says he won’t influence or profit from its clients—ranging from the British Horseracing Authority and energy groups Ovo and Cadent to Netflix—opposition parties and ethics campaigners demand a Cabinet Office probe over perceived conflicts, compounded by Allan’s friendship and political discussions with Strand consultant Tom Baldwin. Labour and the Cabinet Office insist robust safeguards prevent any improper benefit.

articles.title: Housing secretary tells Labour MPs to vote down planning bill amendment
articles.trailText: Amendment restricts protection for animals to allow faster house building
articles.summary: Housing secretary Steve Reed has urged Labour MPs to reject a Lords amendment to the new planning bill that would restore species protections for dormice, badgers, hedgehogs, otters, nightingales and rare habitats by limiting the proposed nature recovery fund to water and air pollution. The draft bill lets developers bypass environmental surveys and mitigation by paying into the fund, drawing “cash to trash” criticism from ecologists and warnings of ecological harm and legal uncertainty from major charities. Critics also highlight ministers’ far greater access to developers than environmental groups, while government insists the amendment would impede vital homebuilding.

articles.title: Who supports Reform and why? The charts that show who favours Farage’s party
articles.trailText: Based on largest poll of supporters, these charts and maps show five distinct groups that could hand Reform a majority
articles.summary: Hope Not Hate’s poll of 11,342 Reform UK supporters identifies five voter clusters—Working Right (26%), Hardline Conservatives (18%), Squeezed Stewards (29%), Reluctant Reformers (19%) and Contrarian Youth (9%)—across age, class and region. While immigration unites some, groups differ sharply on cost of living, economy, climate action and workers’ rights. Squeezed Stewards and Working Right dominate post-industrial northern “red wall” seats; Hardline Conservatives and Squeezed Stewards spread in southern and commuter areas. These internal splits complicate policy priorities but highlight dozens of marginal constituencies where small shifts could hand Reform a decisive victory.

articles.title: Reform UK accused of embracing racism over its pick for head of student organisation
articles.trailText: Matthew Goodwin argued people from minority ethnic backgrounds born and raised in UK were not always British
articles.summary: Reform UK has made hard-right activist and academic-turned-supporter Matthew Goodwin honorary president of its new Students4Reform body after he argued on X that UK-born people from immigrant backgrounds aren’t truly British, citing jihadist 7/7 bombers and a Huntingdon train stabbing as evidence of 'mass uncontrolled immigration'. Lib Dem home affairs spokesman Max Wilkinson called his rhetoric a disgrace. Critics from Labour also demand Nigel Farage strip Goodwin of his role. Goodwin denies racism, blaming integration failures and cultural retention among first- and second-generation immigrants. Reform UK has been contacted for comment.

articles.title: Thin majorities and chaotic strategy push Labour MPs toward regime change
articles.trailText: Frustration with Starmer’s lack of visibility unlikely to be quelled by No 10 efforts to show up leadership challengers
articles.summary: Labour MPs with wafer-thin Commons majorities have grown exasperated with Keir Starmer’s erratic No 10 strategy, low public profile and failure to build personal loyalty. Recent operations aim to smoke out leadership rivals—chiefly Wes Streeting, plus Andy Burnham, Bridget Phillipson, Shabana Mahmood and Angela Rayner—by warning of market turmoil or damaged US relations if contenders veer left. After a rallying conference speech on anti-racism, promised increases in press access, UK travel and engagement repeatedly faltered: Starmer has not held a UK press conference in over a month, yet spent three foreign trips before the budget. MPs now openly discuss regime change.

articles.title: UK cuts contribution to Aids, tuberculosis and malaria fund by £150m
articles.trailText: Campaigners say 15% cut, which is smaller than had been feared, is serious setback in efforts to combat the diseases
articles.summary: The UK announced a 15% reduction in its Global Fund pledge to combat AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, committing £850m for 2027-29 versus £1bn previously. Aid groups warn this £150m cut risks up to 255,000 preventable deaths and undermines decades of progress, with potential disruptions to treatment and prevention services. Government officials argue this remains a strong vote of confidence amid wider overseas aid cuts, but Labour figures and NGOs decry it as a moral failure that could hamper efforts to end these diseases by 2030.

articles.title: Racism returning to UK politics – and people are very scared, says Starmer
articles.trailText: PM attacks ‘toxic division of Reform’ and gives strongest signal yet that two-child benefit cap will be lifted
articles.summary: PM Keir Starmer warns Nigel Farage’s Reform UK is reviving “racist and divisive” politics that “makes people feel very scared,” drawing battle lines between Labour’s “patriotic national renewal” and Reform’s “toxic division.” On ITV Lorraine he signalled lifting the two-child benefit cap—the main driver of child poverty—pledging further measures beyond free meals, at an estimated £3.5bn cost by 2029-30, and echoed calls by Rachel Reeves and Wes Streeting to end racism.

articles.title: Your Party row erupts over hundreds of thousands of pounds in donations
articles.trailText: Clash the latest in months of political infighting between the camps of Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana
articles.summary: Your Party’s founders Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana are locked in a public dispute over MOU Operations Ltd’s donations, with Sultana offering £600,000 of an alleged £850,000 pot while insisting on retaining funds for legal and admin costs. Corbyn’s allies demand the full sum and threaten legal action, rejecting her proposal. The row over an additional £500,000 from an unauthorized membership portal intensifies as the party gears up for a leadership contest and national conference. Sultana says reserves are needed to cover refunds; critics accuse her of political gamesmanship.

articles.title: Maybe the BBC can learn a thing or two about fake news from Trump | John Crace
articles.trailText: The broadcaster didn’t make a very good job of its untruth – possibly because it hasn’t had as much practice
articles.summary: In this satirical column, John Crace skewers Donald Trump’s labeling of the BBC as “100% fake news” and contrasts his brazen falsehoods with the broadcaster’s rare misstep: a Panorama editing error that spliced two Trump clips, prompting apologies and the resignation of top executives. Amid a pitchfork-wielding backlash from figures across the spectrum—Nigel Farage, Kemi Badenoch and ambivalent Labour leaders—the BBC’s impartiality and licence fee face fresh attacks, even as supporters like Ed Davey defend its global credibility.

articles.title: MPs preparing to examine Chinese state influence at British universities
articles.trailText: Committee’s inquiry into review of UK-China relations to be broadened after Sheffield Hallam University disclosures
articles.summary: MPs on the foreign affairs select committee will broaden their China audit to probe alleged Beijing interference at UK universities after The Guardian revealed Sheffield Hallam University barred professor Laura Murphy’s Uyghur forced-labor research under Chinese pressure. Sheffield Hallam was referred to counter-terrorism police, and staff plan strikes over job cuts and the handling of the case. The committee, chaired by Emily Thornberry, and UCU unions demand a full public inquiry and review of commercial pressures eroding academic freedom. Critics warn UK HEIs’ reliance on Chinese student fees and collaborations risks foreign influence. Beijing condemns the case as US-backed propaganda.

articles.title: Billionaire Tory donor gives £200,000 to Reform UK
articles.trailText: JCB chair Lord Bamford hands equal amount to Tories and Reform to support parties he says ‘believe in small business’
articles.summary: Lord Bamford, JCB chair and billionaire Conservative donor with family wealth of £9.5bn, has donated £200,000 to Nigel Farage’s Reform UK, matching a gift to the Conservative Party. JCB, the world’s third-largest construction-equipment maker with £5.8bn turnover and 19,000 employees, says it supports parties that “believe in small business.” Bamford, who retired as a Conservative peer, recently backed Farage by funding a helicopter trip and exhibiting at Reform’s conference. Reform, currently leading in polls, is targeting SMEs and sole traders, launching a “small business for Reform” lobby backed by entrepreneurs like Checkatrade’s Kevin Byrne.

articles.title: Lady Howells of St Davids obituary
articles.trailText: Community worker and champion of racial equality who became a spokeswoman for the family of Stephen Lawrence
articles.summary: Rosalind Patricia-Anne Howells, Lady Howells of St Davids (1931–2025), was a Grenada-born community worker and racial equality campaigner who emigrated to Britain in 1951. After training as a librarian and social worker, she spent decades in south London leading housing, education and health initiatives, directed equal opportunities for Greenwich Council (1980–87), chaired Lewisham Racial Equality Council (1994–97) and earned an OBE in 1994. From 1999 to 2019 she sat in the House of Lords, became spokeswoman for Stephen Lawrence’s family, held diplomatic, academic and trustee roles, and was a lifelong Labour activist. She is survived by daughter Anne, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

articles.title: Can Nigel Farage emulate success enjoyed by Italy’s far-right Giorgia Meloni?
articles.trailText: Reform’s leader may hope to tread a similar path to Italy’s prime minister, but she is an experienced parliamentarian open to collaboration and compromise
articles.summary: Since her 2022 election, Italy’s PM Giorgia Meloni has shifted from hard-right populism and neo-fascist origins toward pragmatic governance, boosting labor visas, outsourcing asylum claims to Albania, and forging G7 alliances, earning respect from peers like Keir Starmer, thanks to her multilingualism and flexibility. Reform UK’s Nigel Farage has similarly mainstreamed his hard-right rhetoric while shunning extremist partners and dropping pledged tax cuts, but lacks Meloni’s two decades in parliament and ministerial bargaining experience. Observers question whether Farage’s historically autocratic style and limited governance background equip him for the compromises essential to stable national leadership.

articles.title: AI-powered nimbyism could grind UK planning system to a halt, experts warn
articles.trailText: Tools that help people scan applications and find grounds for objection have potential to hit government’s housebuilding plans
articles.summary: New AI services like Objector (£45) and Planningobjection.com (£99) automatically scan UK planning applications, rank objection grounds and generate letters, speeches and videos to help local opponents. Founders say they level the playing field; lawyers warn mass AI objections—sometimes citing non-existent case law—could overwhelm planning committees and stall government housing targets. Objector uses dual AI models to reduce hallucinations and plans to expand to larger developments. The government meanwhile backs AI tools (Extract, Consult) to speed approvals and analyse public feedback, risking an AI ‘arms race’ between builders and nimby activists.

articles.title: Developers met ministers dozens of times over planning bill while ecologists were shut out
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Leading ecologists say warnings over threat to wildlife have been ignored in drive to build 1.5m new homes
articles.summary: Labour’s planning and infrastructure bill, aimed at easing environmental safeguards to deliver 1.5 million homes, has seen chancellor Rachel Reeves and housing minister Matthew Pennycook meet dozens of developers (Berkeley, Barratt, Taylor Wimpey, Vistry) while the Chartered Institute of Ecology and Environmental Management was denied ministerial access. Peers in the Lords won an amendment to protect dormice, nightingales, hedgehogs and ancient habitats, but ministers have resisted, prompting warnings of a public backlash over sidelining nature experts.

articles.title: Plant importers say border delays in Kent could drive up prices and stop deliveries from EU
articles.trailText: Traders report long waits at Sevington inspection post and claim trees and shrubs are repeatedly being damaged
articles.summary: Importers warn that stringent post-Brexit plant inspections at Kent’s Sevington border control, reopened April 2024, are causing multi-day waits, adding ~£200 per load and damaging trees and shrubs during reloading. Traders report olive trees held five days, daily floral shipments delayed in waves and risk hauliers abandoning UK deliveries. Operating costs (£23m/yr, £29-£145 per consignment) and damage claims fuel calls for an SPS agreement with the EU by 2027. Government and operators Sodexo/Kuehne+Nagel say procedures are under review as ministers pursue a biosecurity deal to cut costs and red tape.

articles.title: Cutting aid for disease fund would be moral failure, Labour MPs tell Starmer
articles.trailText: UK expected to reduce contribution to Global Fund to Fight Aids, Tuberculosis and Malaria by 20%
articles.summary: Seven ex-junior ministers under Keir Starmer have privately warned the prime minister that a planned 20% cut in the UK’s £1 billion pledge (to £800 million) for the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria would be both a moral failure and a strategic disaster. They stress past cuts to Gavi and looming reductions in UK aid from 0.7% to 0.3% of national income risk reversing decades of progress—saving 70 million lives since 2002—and could cause up to 340,000 avoidable deaths or nearly 6 million new infections. A recent poll finds 62% of Britons oppose the cut. Foreign Office officials insist the UK remains committed to global health and stability.

articles.title: A rats to riches story: Larry the Downing Street cat finds place in TV spotlight
articles.trailText: Popularity of Britain’s top mouser – ‘the guy to meet in No 10’ – to feature in documentary series
articles.summary: Larry, the 18-year-old chief mouser at 10 Downing Street, was adopted from Battersea in 2011 to tackle rodents and has since served six prime ministers, becoming a symbol of nonpartisan continuity. He’ll feature in Channel 4’s documentary 'David Baddiel: Cat Man', where his duties—greeting guests, inspecting security and napping on antique furniture—take centre stage. Larry’s spontaneous appearances during live broadcasts and visits by world leaders (Obama, Zelenskyy) have made him a media star with a devoted social-media following and fan mail. He’s weathered feuds (notably with FO cat Palmerston), political grumbles (Theresa May, Andrew Marr) and remains funded by voluntary staff contributions.

articles.title: Remaining four ‘rebel’ Labour MPs have whip restored
articles.trailText: Neil Duncan-Jordan, Chris Hinchliff, Brian Leishman and Rachael Maskell are last of series of penalised backbenchers to return to the party
articles.summary: In November 2025 the four Labour backbenchers Neil Duncan-Jordan, Chris Hinchliff, Brian Leishman and Rachael Maskell had the party whip restored after being stripped of it in July for rebelling over welfare cuts, winter fuel allowance and planning reforms. Following a review and talks with chief whip Jonathan Reynolds, they rejoined the parliamentary party, marking the final reinstatement in a series that began with the return of seven MPs earlier in the year. Only a handful of former Labour MPs, including Zarah Sultana and Diane Abbott, remain independents.

articles.title: Boris Johnson trying to undermine BBC leadership, insiders fear after leak
articles.trailText: Director general under pressure after release of memo criticising reporting on Trump, trans rights and Gaza
articles.summary: Insiders warn Boris Johnson and associates, notably ex-Downing Street communications director Robbie Gibb, are using the leak of a Michael Prescott memo to undermine BBC director-general Tim Davie and influence the corporation ahead of its charter renewal. Prescott’s memo criticises BBC coverage of Trump (including a disputed Panorama edit), Gaza and trans rights. After Johnson demanded Davie “explain or resign” and MPs set a response deadline, the BBC board—where Gibb sits—prepares its defence as Prescott readies to testify.

articles.title: Greens’ ‘undeliverable’ promises will let voters down, says Labour minister
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Darren Jones says Labour has to convince young people it is ‘modern party of the future’
articles.summary: Darren Jones, the prime minister’s chief secretary, warns the Green party is offering “simple solutions to complex problems” and making “undeliverable” pledges that risk disappointing voters, likening them to a populist left version of Reform UK. With Labour polling just 4 points ahead of the Greens (16% vs 6.7% in 2019), he insists Labour will not backtrack on net zero and must prove itself a “modern party” by funding renewables, reforming public services—including AI-driven civil service reductions—and delivering realistic tax and digital ID reforms to win back progressive and young voters before a likely showdown with Nigel Farage’s faction.

articles.title: Nicola Sturgeon: I understand why people doubt my ignorance of alleged SNP embezzlement
articles.trailText: ‘Trust me, I had no idea’ about potential wrongdoing in Scottish National party, says former first minister
articles.summary: Former first minister Nicola Sturgeon insists she was unaware of alleged embezzlement by SNP chief executive Peter Murrell despite police searches of their Glasgow home, party HQ and a parked motorhome after her February 2023 resignation. She argues her relaxed post-resignation demeanour proves her ignorance, noting she’s no longer under investigation and Murrell, now charged, hasn’t pleaded. Sturgeon warns rising nationalism in Scotland, Wales and Reform UK may fracture the union toward confederation or independence and defends her stalled gender recognition reforms.

articles.title: Kemi Badenoch to relaunch exclusive ‘advisory board’ for high-value donors
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tory leader has plans to reinstate group that provided top donors with direct access to senior ministers
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch plans to revive the Conservative party’s exclusive advisory board for high-value donors under a new name, restoring top givers’ direct access to her and shadow ministers to shape policy. The scheme was disbanded in 2021 after a cash-for-access scandal involving figures like Mohamed Amersi and meetings with Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak. Facing fundraising pressure post-election and competition from Reform UK, the Tories have nonetheless raised £8.4m this year, including £2m from video-game tycoon Jez San and £200k from industrialist Chris Rea.

articles.title: Nandy breached code over appointment of donor to lead football regulator
articles.trailText: Culture secretary ‘deeply regrets error’ after inquiry finds failures in declaring past donations by watchdog nominee
articles.summary: Culture secretary Lisa Nandy apologised to PM Keir Starmer after William Shawcross’s report found she failed to declare David Kogan’s past donations to her and Labour before nominating him to head the new Independent Football Regulator. The 18-page inquiry cited three governance code breaches, including omission of Kogan’s donations in interview discussions. Starmer accepted her inadvertent error, praised her integrity and willingness to learn lessons, while Kogan keeps his role. Shawcross recommended clearer conflict-of-interest guidance and reminded ministers to declare all relevant interests promptly.

articles.title: Lucy Powell says Labour must stand by promise not to raise key taxes
articles.trailText: New deputy leader also calls on government to lift two-child benefit cap urgently and in full
articles.summary: Labour deputy leader Lucy Powell urged her party to honour its manifesto pledge not to raise income tax, national insurance or VAT, warning that breaking it would erode trust. Positioning herself as an independent voice unbound by collective responsibility, she demanded a “budget of fairness” boosting household incomes and a full, urgent repeal of the two-child benefit cap to curb child poverty. Her BBC intervention ramps up pressure on Rachel Reeves’s budget choices and highlights internal tensions over funding public services versus upholding election promises.

articles.title: Why doesn’t Lammy just bring in a new policy of accidentally jailing people? | John Crace
articles.trailText: Justice secretary seemed to be the only person not being released, as he hid from questions about latest prison mishaps
articles.summary: John Crace skewers justice secretary David Lammy’s chaotic handling of repeated accidental prisoner releases—from an Algerian sex offender to the reformed con Billy Smith—while he’s effectively imprisoned by civil servants on 15-minute observation. Lammy dodges PMQs, blames a doppelgänger and Tory underfunding, and forgets crucial updates. The satirical piece even proposes a right-wing dream policy of “accidentally jailing” migrants, lampooning his PR blunders as emblematic of a collapsing prison system.

articles.title: Reform UK suspends another member of Kent county council
articles.trailText: Isabella Kemp’s departure means party has lost nine of 57 councillors elected in May, including four after video leak
articles.summary: Reform UK has suspended Kent county councillor Isabella Kemp, its ninth loss since May, amid fallout from a leaked video of leader Linden Kemkaran berating colleagues. Kemp, former adult social care chair and party data protection officer, intends to take unfair dismissal claims to a tribunal via Acas. Four councillors were earlier suspended after the leak, with two forming an Independent Reformers group. The turmoil forced cancellation of key committee meetings and cast doubt on promised savings, while prompting questions over a possible 5% council tax rise and drawing criticism from opposition and local leaders.

articles.title: Badenoch accused of ‘interfering’ in lobbying scandal linked to Cameron
articles.trailText: Lex Greensill alleges current Tory leader used business secretary position to protect former PM from scrutiny
articles.summary: Lex Greensill has accused Tory leader Kemi Badenoch of ‘interfering’ in a 2023 insolvency inquiry to protect David Cameron from scrutiny over his Greensill lobbying role. In a letter to new business secretary Peter Kyle, Greensill alleges Badenoch, as business secretary, restructured the Insolvency Service case to omit Cameron’s involvement ahead of his elevation to the Lords and appointment as foreign secretary. He argues this political intervention undermines the disqualification proceedings against him and calls for a full review amid ongoing UK, German and Swiss probes.

articles.title: Labour MPs revive ‘desperately needed’ soft left group to take on Reform
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tribune hopes over 100 MPs join group led by Vicky Foxcroft and former cabinet minister Louise Haigh
articles.summary: Labour MPs led by Louise Haigh and Vicky Foxcroft have relaunched the Tribune group to organise the party’s soft left ahead of the budget, targeting over 100 supporters. Architects of last year’s welfare rebellion—including Justin Madders, Sarah Owen and Debbie Abrahams—and new intake MPs Yuan Yang and Beccy Cooper will steer the caucus. They aim to pressurise the government to abandon the two-child benefit cap, adopt a more muscular centre-left stance against Reform and the Greens, and revive Tribune’s 1960s progressive legacy after years of dormancy under Starmer.

articles.title: Lancashire’s Reform-run council plans to close care homes and day centres
articles.trailText: Questions about potential conflict of interest as council’s cabinet member for social care owns private care company
articles.summary: Reform UK–run Lancashire county council proposes closing five care homes and five day centres to save £4.16m a year, part of £103m cuts including £50m in adult social services over 2025–27. Residents such as 92-year-old Dorothy Devereux vow to resist, while Phil Price says the plan could “kill” his mother and will quit the party. Critics call it “selling off the family silver” and allege conflict of interest against social care cabinet member Graham Dalton, co-owner of private 1st for Care GB. A consultation runs until mid-December, with a final decision due in February.

articles.title: Reform’s public-sector pensions plan could cost billions extra, union warns
articles.trailText: Prospect says proposals to make payouts less generous would damage public finances rather than save money
articles.summary: Reform UK deputy leader Richard Tice proposes replacing defined benefit public-sector pensions for new entrants with defined contribution schemes to curb an unfunded £1.5–2.5 trn liability. Prospect union warns the switch would strip current contributions, cost taxpayers tens of billions long term, aggravate staffing shortages and create a fiscal “ticking timebomb.” Tice argues mirroring private-sector reforms is vital to prevent debt spiraling to 200% of GDP, while the OBR maintains existing pension costs are sustainable under its projections.

articles.title: London mayor sees parallels in Zohran Mamdani’s victory: ‘Hope won’
articles.trailText: Sadiq Khan, the city’s first Muslim mayor, says: ‘We are united by something far more fundamental, our belief in the power of politics to change people’s lives for the better’
articles.summary: Sadiq Khan, London’s first Muslim mayor, hailed Zohran Mamdani’s victory in New York—by almost 200,000 votes over Andrew Cuomo—as a win for hope over fear. From a Rio climate summit, Khan noted parallels in their ‘soft-left’ platforms: rent controls, high living wages (£14.80/hr vs $30/hr), fare freezes/free transit, and a 2% levy on incomes above $1 million. Both champions of Gaza recognition, they’ve endured right-wing slurs (Trump, Goldsmith, Cuomo) but insist multicultural, progressive cities reject dystopian fear-mongering, proving unity and optimism always triumph. Khan, re-elected for a historic third term, and Mamdani, son of Ugandan academic Mahmood Mamdani and filmmaker Mira Nair, embody diverse, progressive leadership.

articles.title: Miscounting to six costs Tory stand-in his gotcha against poppy-shock Lammy | John Crace
articles.trailText: Plucked from obscurity, James Cartlidge messed up his maths while his opposite number had forgotten his politics 101
articles.summary: At PMQs, Tory shadow defence secretary James Cartlidge, standing in for Keir Starmer–away at COP30–miscounted his six allotted questions while trying to nail Labour’s David Lammy over allegedly released asylum-seeker sex offenders. Cartlidge’s procedural fumbles and unfounded claims collapsed his ‘gotcha’, leaving Rishi Sunak distracted by a prostate cancer question and frontbenchers scrambling. Lammy, who also nearly sparked controversy by arriving poppy-less, salvaged his credibility when a veteran supplied one and defended Labour’s record on justice system failings. The episode spotlighted chaos in the Conservative deputy ranks and ongoing debate on prison release procedures.

articles.title: Letter: Prunella Scales obituary
articles.trailText: Neil Kinnock writes: Prunella Scales was a dedicated member of the Labour party
articles.summary: Neil Kinnock praises Prunella Scales as a brilliant comic and dramatic actor and committed political activist. As a leading Equity union member and lifelong Labour party supporter (like husband Tim West), she championed CND, the Anti-Apartheid Movement, the Anti-Nazi League and women in mining communities, alongside charity work. Known for her lauded portrayal of the Queen in Alan Bennett’s 1988 A Question of Attribution—achieved by studying newsreels—she embodied both artistry and civic engagement. Her personal motto—'Sometimes, dear, it’s useful to stand up and show that you are taking action and not acting'—underscored her belief in visible activism.

articles.title: Reeves wants to talk about the budget, but she’s taken a vow of white noise | John Crace
articles.trailText: Exclusive: It must be tough overseeing Schrödinger’s economy, fixing the foundations while also failing to fix them
articles.summary: At an 8.10 am Downing Street briefing, chancellor Rachel Reeves abandoned her traditional pre-budget silence for a 40-minute “interpretative dance” of coded messages and white noise, hinting at income tax rises without naming them. Claiming honesty while reneging on manifesto pledges against tax hikes, she portrayed the UK economy as simultaneously fixed and flawed—Schrödinger’s economy—downplaying OBR forecasts as backward-looking. Critics call it damage control ahead of 26 November. Meanwhile, Tory leadership contender Kemi Badenoch staged an inconsequential outdoor press-fest that few noticed.

articles.title: French taxi driver cleared of stealing from David Lammy after fare dispute
articles.trailText: Nassim Mimun, who left with Lammy’s and his wife’s bags after ‘tone escalated’, acquitted owing to lack of evidence
articles.summary: French court acquitted taxi driver Nassim Mimun, 40, of theft charges after allegedly taking cash and luggage belonging to UK deputy prime minister David Lammy and his wife at the end of a 600 km ride from Forlì, Italy, to Flaine in April. Mimun claimed Lammy refused to pay a €700 balance on a €1,550 booking and held their bags overnight, returning them to a police station the next day. Both parties filed complaints, but prosecutors said there was insufficient evidence to convict. Lammy, then foreign secretary, became justice secretary and deputy PM in September.

articles.title: Starmer was briefed on Mandelson’s Epstein links before appointing him, say civil servants
articles.trailText: PM had been given ‘summary of reputational risks’ but did not know about contents of emails before PMQs, MPs told
articles.summary: Senior civil servants told MPs that Keir Starmer received a Cabinet Office report on Peter Mandelson’s US ambassadorial candidacy, which flagged “prior relationship with Jeffrey Epstein” (including a 2009 stay at Epstein’s Manhattan flat and a 2002 meeting with Tony Blair), his past ministerial resignations and other reputational risks. The appointment proceeded before national security vetting was finalised. Starmer did not see Mandelson’s emails expressing support for Epstein before endorsing him at PMQs; their later publication prompted Mandelson’s removal. The government now mandates pre-appointment interviews and ministerial “fireside chats” for political ambassadorial posts.

articles.title: Nige is no longer laughing at himself as he ‘performs’ yet another big speech | John Crace
articles.trailText: Reform leader is trying to make it as a mainstream politician – which involves contradicting himself and gaslighting voters
articles.summary: At a showy City press conference set to ‘perform’ another economy speech, Reform UK’s Nigel Farage shed his self-mockery to pose as a mainstream politician. He recycled stale Brexit criticism while absolving himself of responsibility and gaslighting voters over tax cuts ‘aspirations.’ Attacking Labour and Tory MPs as inept, championing the wealthy over low-income families and pensioners, and scapegoating immigrants, Farage contradicted past pledges, flattered a young male audience and sidelined colleagues to cultivate credibility without substance.

articles.title: What would UK economic policy look like under Nigel Farage’s Reform?
articles.trailText: Leader’s speech offered most detailed explanation yet on party’s priorities on tax cuts, benefits, wages and pensions
articles.summary: In his most detailed outline to date, Nigel Farage framed Reform UK’s six economic priorities: he downgraded but retained the aspiration to raise the income-tax threshold to £20k, pledged only to reverse farm inheritance-tax hikes, and proposed tightening personal independence payments while lifting the two-child benefit cap solely for working UK nationals. He hinted at scrapping the triple lock and cutting public-sector pension fees, celebrated wealthy entrepreneurs as vital growth drivers, pledged new North Sea drilling to replace net-zero targets, and railed against diversity and compliance regimes as over-regulation.

articles.title: Nigel Farage backtracks on Reform UK’s promise to cut £90bn of taxes
articles.trailText: Party leader says proposal had been an ‘aspiration’ and accuses Tories and Labour of ‘wrecking the public finances’
articles.summary: Nigel Farage has partially reversed Reform UK’s pledge to cut £90bn of taxes, calling it an “aspiration” and insisting major cuts follow public spending control. He refused to guarantee the pensions triple lock and delayed significant tax reductions, offering only modest initial savings like higher thresholds and farm inheritance relief. Farage outlined deep welfare, net zero and asylum policy cuts, potential public sector pension reforms, and disputed PIP savings. He argued the youth minimum wage may be too high, attacked non-dom tax rules to retain high earners, lamented squandered post-Brexit deregulation, and declined to name a prospective chancellor, dubbing his economic team “a work in progress.”

articles.title: Nigel Farage to promise business deregulation in economic policy speech
articles.trailText: Reform UK leader to set out ‘pro-entrepreneurship’ agenda while rowing back on tax cuts pledge
articles.summary: Nigel Farage will unveil Reform UK’s most detailed economic policy yet, centring on sweeping business deregulation and pro-entrepreneurship measures in lieu of previously pledged £90bn tax cuts. Framing deregulation as a post-Brexit opportunity, he promises to rein in public spending to reduce borrowing costs before cutting taxes and to recruit industry experts into government. The speech seeks to bolster fiscal credibility and diversify Reform’s image beyond migration, though economists warn that his proposed spending cuts and £45bn net-zero rollback savings may be unachievable.

articles.title: Tory patience wears thin as Badenoch’s critics count down to May elections
articles.trailText: With the party adrift and Reform surging, Jenrick’s allies are sharpening their pitch for a post-election reset
articles.summary: At a VIP Tory event, debate swirled over Kemi Badenoch's potential ouster as Reform UK surges and local elections loom. Robert Jenrick—her runner-up in last year's leadership contest—leads calls for a post-May reset, eyeing the 36 MPs needed to trigger a confidence vote. Though Badenoch’s stamp-duty cut buys her breathing space, polls show her at –22 favourability, lagging Jenrick (–16). Ministers diverge on whether to replace her pre- or post-elections; contenders include Jenrick, James Cleverly, Mel Stride or lower-profile figures like Claire Coutinho. A pact with Reform remains divisive.

articles.title: Rachel Reeves considers 20% tax on assets of people deciding to leave UK
articles.trailText: Plans for ‘settling-up charge’ predicted to raise £2bn and would follow policy in place among most G7 countries
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves is exploring a ‘settling-up charge’ requiring wealthy UK residents who emigrate to pay 20% tax on their retained business assets, aligning the UK with most G7 nations and potentially raising £2bn. Currently, non-UK residents pay 20% CGT on UK property over £6,000 but can avoid tax on other assets like shareholdings after departure. The proposed measure would tax unrealised gains on assets at exit, with options to defer payment. Treasury modelling is underway ahead of the budget, balancing risks of capital flight against fairness. A complementary plan could waive CGT on pre-arrival gains to attract investors.

articles.title: HMRC likely to have breached privacy laws in stopping child benefit – experts
articles.trailText: Watchdog contacts tax authority after families’ payments stopped based on flawed travel data
articles.summary: HMRC suspended child benefit for some 23,500 families under an anti-fraud crackdown using incomplete Home Office travel data, reinstating 1,979 payments so far after legal experts warned the flawed information breached UK data protection rules. The ICO has opened inquiries, urging that inter-departmental data sharing be necessary, accurate and proportionate. HMRC halted suspensions pending further checks, now cross-referencing travel records with PAYE data. Ministers face calls to explain failures and compensate affected households.

articles.title: Reform councillor defects to Tories after party’s policies left him ‘uncomfortable’
articles.trailText: Dartford representative James Buchan says ‘devastating’ immigration plans had created a lot of fear and anxiety
articles.summary: James Buchan, Reform UK councillor for Dartford’s Stone House ward in Kent, has defected to the Conservatives, citing discomfort with Nigel Farage’s anti-immigration agenda—particularly a plan to remove indefinite leave to remain for non-EU residents. Elected in a July by-election to serve local families, Buchan said fear-based rhetoric created anxiety and clashed with community service. A Reform source claims he should resign, while Tory council leader Jeremy Kite welcomed him. The move follows scrutiny of Farage over a racist MP defense and a bribery plea by his former Welsh leader.

articles.title: Ex-Tory member sues party over suspension for criticising Israel
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Bruce MacInnes, whose grandfather was archbishop of Jerusalem, told genocide remarks were antisemitic
articles.summary: Bruce MacInnes, a member since 2018 and grandson of Jerusalem’s former Anglican archbishop, is suing the Conservative party for £30,000 after a six-month suspension for labeling Israel’s actions in Gaza “genocide”. Party officials deemed his repeated references to the ICC’s plausible genocide finding antisemitic and say they emailed him, though he received no notices. MacInnes claims breach of contract and belief-based discrimination, highlighting opaque governance and suppression of pro-Palestinian views. Former foreign minister Sir Alan Duncan brands the suspension “McCarthyism”. MacInnes awaits a high-court date, having already incurred substantial legal fees.

articles.title: Bridget Phillipson ‘ready to take on unions’ over year 8 reading tests
articles.trailText: Education secretary says mandatory test needed to tackle ‘shocking outcomes’ for many working-class children
